Foramen ovale, foramen spinosum, superior orbital fissure

questions.text: The divisions of the trigeminal nerve exit the cranial cavity through which of the following foramina
questions.solution:
The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) has three divisions:

  • Ophthalmic division (V1) - its branches exits via the superior orbital fissure
  • Maxillary division (V2) - exits via the foramen rotundum
  • Mandibular division (V3) - exits via the foramen ovale

Option Analysis:

a. Correct

  • Superior orbital fissure → Ophthalmic (V1)
  • Foramen rotundum → Maxillary (V2)
  • Foramen ovale → Mandibular (V3)

b. Incorrect

  • Foramen spinosum transmits the middle meningeal artery, and nervus spinosus (not a primary division of CN V).

c. Incorrect

  • Jugular foramen transmits cranial nerves IX, X, and XI - not CN V.

d. Incorrect

  • Inferior orbital fissure does transmit a branch of the maxillary nerve, specifically the zygomatic nerve (a branch of V2), and infraorbital nerve (continuation of V2) passes into the orbit via this fissure - not a primary exit for any CN V division.
  • Foramen spinosum again, not relevant for trigeminal nerve divisions exits.

Clinical Anatomy Highlight:

  • The trigeminal nerve's divisions and their respective foramina (superior orbital fissure for V1 branches, foramen rotundum for V2, foramen ovale for V3) are critical in clinical practice.
  • Lesions, trauma, infections, or tumours at these sites can lead to sensory deficits, motor weakness, or neuropathic pain, with conditions like trigeminal neuralgia and superior orbital fissure syndrome being particularly relevant.

questions.text: Left ventricular function is affected in various cardiac diseases. A physician advised 58-year-old male to investigate about left ventricular contraction. The duration of left ventricular ejection time (LVET) gives idea about
questions.solution:
• Option c: LVET is the period from the beginning of the carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch.
  • To measure about duration of isovolumetric ventricular contraction is difficult in cardiac disorders.
  • The duration of total electromechanical systole (QS2), the pre-ejection period (PEP), and the left ventricular ejection time (LVET) will help to identify the left ventricular contractile function. It is measured by recording the ECG, phonocardiogram, and carotid pulse simultaneously.
  • Option a: PEP is the difference between QS2 and LVET and represents the time for the electrical as well as the mechanical events that precede systolic ejection.
  • Option b: QS2 is the period from the onset of the QRS complex to the closure of the aortic valves, as determined by the onset of the second heart sound.
  • Option d: The ratio of PEP/LVET increases when left ventricular performance is compromised. Normally it is 0.35.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does NOT participate in the parasympathetic innervation of the submandibular gland
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) supplies parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland via the otic ganglion, not the submandibular gland.
  • Hence, it plays no role in innervating the submandibular gland and is the correct "EXCEPT" answer.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Clinical Anatomy:

  • Lesion in chorda tympani (e.g., during middle ear surgery) can lead to loss of taste in the anterior 2/3 of tongue and reduced salivation from submandibular and sublingual glands.
  • The submandibular ganglion is suspended from the lingual nerve, and the secretomotor fibers synapse here before reaching the submandibular and sublingual glands.
  • An operative procedure on submandibular gland and duct may cause injury to lingual nerve (it loops under submandibular duct at floor of mouth) - leading to not only loss of general sensations on the anterior 2/3 of tongue but also loss of taste sensation and decreased salivary secretions.

Parasympathetic (secretomotor) supply of salivary glands:

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male chef presents to the clinic with complaints of severe burning pain in his hands after cutting hot chili peppers. He reports accidental contact with the chili juice on his skin, which led to an intense, prolonged burning sensation that worsened when he washed his hands with warm water. He denies any visible skin lesions or other systemic symptoms.
Which of the following best explains the receptor involved and its activation in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Variety of receptors on the endings of nociceptive sensory nerves respond to noxious thermal, mechanical, or chemical stimuli. These are part of a family of nonselective cation channels called transient receptor potential (TRP) channels.

  • Option b: TRPV1 receptors are activated by noxious heat (>43°C) and capsaicin, a chemical found in chili peppers. Capsaicin binds to these receptors, causing the burning sensation described in the case. Warm water exacerbates the sensation by further stimulating TRPV1 receptors.
  • Option a: The burning sensation in this case is not due to mechanical stimulation but chemical activation of TRPV1 receptors by capsaicin from the chili peppers.
  • Option c: TRPM8 receptors are activated by cool temperatures and menthol but are unrelated to the burning sensation caused by capsaicin. Here there is no exposure to cold or menthol.
  • Option d: As option b is correct choice, Option d is incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following fibers are classified as mossy fibers in the cerebellum, EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Olivocerebellar fibers: Not mossy
    • These are climbing fibers and arise from the inferior olivary nucleus. They terminate directly on the dendrites of Purkinje cells, causing powerful excitatory postsynaptic potentials. These are the only fibers classified as climbing fibers.
  • Spinocerebellar fibers: Mossy fibers
    • These fibers carry proprioceptive input from the spinal cord and terminate on granule cells in the cerebellar cortex via mossy fiber input.
  • Pontocerebellar fibers: Mossy fibers
    • These are part of the corticopontocerebellar pathway, relaying motor plan signals from the cerebral cortex to the cerebellum. They end in the granule cell layer and are classified as mossy fibers.
  • Reticulocerebellar fibers: Mossy fibers
    • These afferents arise from the reticular formation and also terminate in the cerebellar cortex as mossy fibers.

Clinical Anatomy in Brief:

  • Mossy fibers lesion = present movement is distorted
    • Type of deficit: Proprioceptive/motor execution
    • Clinical signs: Ataxia, hypotonia, dysmetria, disrupted coordination
  • Climbing fibers lesion = future movement doesn't improve
    • Type of deficit: Motor learning/adaptation
    • Clinical signs: Poor motor learning, error correction severely impaired

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of the reentry phenomenon in arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
• Option c: A key feature of re-entry is a unidirectional transient block, which allows the electrical impulse to travel retrogradely through the tissue. This transient block can be due to differences in refractory periods or conduction velocity. Without such a block, the impulse would not re-enter the circuit, and the arrhythmia would not sustain.
  • Option a: Re-entry does not depend on a single ectopic pacemaker. Instead, it involves the re-excitation of cardiac tissue through a self-sustaining circuit. This is distinct from arrhythmias driven by ectopic pacemaker activity, which originate from a single focus of abnormal automaticity or triggered activity.
  • Option b: Re-entry can also occur through functional pathways where conduction is altered by transient changes in tissue properties (e.g., ischemia). Anatomical permanent blocks usually do not produce this phenomenon.
  • Option d: While option c is correct, options a and b do not universally describe reentry. This makes "All of the above" an incorrect answer.

questions.text: Identify the Incorrect statements in connection to functions of Heme Containing Proteins.
questions.solution:
Hemoglobin, Myoglobin, Cytochrome C, Cytochrome P 450, Catalase and Tryptophan Pyrrolase all are Heme Containing Proteins involved in various Biological Reactions as mentioned in below table. Although Tryptophan Pyrrolase is involved in Oxidation instead of Hydrolysis of Tryptophan amino acids.

Option D) Catalase is a hemoprotein containing four heme groups. It can act as a peroxidase, catalyzing reactions, but it is also able to catalyze the breakdown of H2O2 formed by the action of oxygenases to water and oxygen. It is one of the fastest enzyme reactions known, destroying millions of potentially damaging H2O2 molecules per second.

Option C) Tryptophan is degraded to amphibolic intermediates via the kynurenine-anthranilate pathway with enzyme Tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase, (tryptophan pyrrolase)

Cytochrome P450 are an important super-family of heme containing monooxygenases, located in endoplasmic Reticulum in liver, Intestine and also in mitochondria responsible for Drug Metabolism and Detoxification.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female non-smoker is evaluated for a lung mass found incidentally on a chest X-ray. A biopsy shows glandular structures with mucin production and the presence of extracellular mucin pools. What is the most likely pathological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Squamous cell carcinoma: This typically shows keratinization and is more common in smokers.n
  2. Adenocarcinoma: This is correct. The presence of glandular structures and mucin production is characteristic of adenocarcinoma, especially in non-smokers.
  3. Large cell carcinoma: This is a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have the glandular features seen here.
  4. Mesothelioma: This typically arises from pleural surfaces and would not show glandular structures. P16, BAP1 MUTATIONS

Key Takeaway:

  • Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer, n non-smokers and is characterized by glandular differentiation and mucin production.
  • It has:
    • Tan-white cut surface
    • May have central area of scar or necrosis
    • Usually well defined but nonencapsulated
  • Invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma: invasion > 5 mm, composed of goblet or columnar cells with abundant mucin.
  • Invasive nonmucinous adenocarcinoma: invasion > 5 mm, glandular differentiation, named by predominant pattern
  • CK7+, CK20-
  • Mutations - KRAS, EGFR
  • OTHER MARKERS - TTF1, NAPSIN

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of nasal congestion, anosmia, and intermittent epistaxis. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the nasal cavity. Biopsy is performed. The biopsy shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. The cells are arranged in a rosette-like pattern, and there is prominent S-100 protein immunoreactivity. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the pathological findings?
questions.solution:
• Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of cancer that arises from the squamous epithelium. It typically shows evidence of squamous differentiation, such as keratinization.
  • Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that arises from the glandular epithelium. It typically shows evidence of glandular differentiation, such as mucin production.
  • Olfactory neuroblastoma: This is the correct answer. Olfactory neuroblastoma is a rare malignant tumor that arises from the olfactory epithelium. It is characterized by small, round, blue cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, arranged in a rosette-like pattern.
  • Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a type of cancer that arises from the bone or soft tissue. It typically shows evidence of neuroectodermal differentiation.

Key Takeaways

MRI/ CT- Dumbbell shaped mass

  1. Olfactory neuroblastoma is a rare malignant tumor that arises from the olfactory epithelium: Olfactory neuroblastoma is a rare tumor that typically presents with nasal congestion, anosmia, and epistaxis.
  2. The tumor cells in olfactory neuroblastoma are typically small, round, and blue, with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.
  3. The tumor cells in olfactory neuroblastoma are typically arranged in a rosette-like pattern, and there is prominent S-100 protein immunoreactivity.
  • Homer Wright pseudorosettes (arrows): neoplastic cells palisading around a central zone of fibrillar neural matrix; their presence in a nasal tumor is characteristic for olfactory neuroblastoma,

choices.text: The adult fluke is found in the liver and causes cirrhosis.
The larvae can be found in the faeces after ingestion of raw or undercooked freshwater fish.
Humans acquire infection by ingesting undercooked or raw freshwater crabs or crayfish.
Paragonimus westermani eggs are expelled through urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct characteristic of Paragonimus westermani, the causative agent of human lung fluke disease?
questions.solution:
1. (A) The adult fluke is found in the liver and causes cirrhosis:
    • False: Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke, not a liver fluke. The adult fluke typically resides in the lungs, where it causes symptoms like cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. Liver flukes (e.g., Fasciola hepatica) cause liver damage, but not Paragonimus.
    • Key Point: Paragonimus westermani primarily infects the lungs, not the liver.
  2. (B) The larvae can be found in the feces after ingestion of raw or undercooked freshwater fish:
    • Key Point: Paragonimus infection involves freshwater crabs/crayfish, not fish, as the intermediate host.
  3. (C) Humans acquire infection by ingesting undercooked or raw freshwater crabs or crayfish:
    • True: The definitive host (humans) acquires Paragonimus westermani infection by ingesting raw or undercooked freshwater crabs or crayfish, which contain the larvae (metacercariae). Once ingested, these larvae migrate to the lungs, where they mature into adults.
    • Key Point: Raw crabs or crayfish are the primary source of infection for Paragonimus westermani.
  4. (D) Paragonimus westermani eggs are expelled through urine:
    • Key Point: Paragonimus eggs are found in sputum or feces, not in urine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke (Trematodes) (Leaf like) that causes symptoms such as chronic cough, haemoptysis, and chest pain.
  • They are monoecious. Infective form - Metacercaciae
  • Humans acquire the infection by consuming raw or undercooked freshwater crabs or crayfish.
  • The eggs of Paragonimus are expelled through sputum or faeces, not urine.
  • The adult fluke resides in the lungs, not the liver.
  • Key words - Endemic haemoptysis or Red brown sputum

Sigmoid sinus and internal jugular vein

questions.text: The emissary vein that passes through the foramen ovale connects which of the following venous channels
questions.solution:
Option a: Cavernous sinus and pharyngeal venous plexus

  • Incorrect. This connection is typically via emissary veins through the foramen lacerum or emissary sphenoidal foramen, less commonly through the foramen ovale.

Option b: Cavernous sinus and pterygoid venous plexus

  • Correct. The emissary vein passing through the foramen ovale connects the cavernous sinus with the pterygoid venous plexus, serving as a potential route for infection from extracranial to intracranial compartments.

Option c: Sigmoid sinus and internal jugular vein

  • Incorrect. This connection is a direct continuation at the jugular foramen, not mediated by emissary veins.

Option d: Sigmoid sinus and suboccipital venous plexus

  • Incorrect. This is via the posterior condylar emissary vein, not the foramen ovale.

Emissary Veins - Key MCQ-Oriented Points

Definition & Importance

  • Valveless veins that connect extracranial veins to intracranial dural venous sinuses.
  • Allow bidirectional blood flow, hence can transmit infections (e.g., from face to cranial cavity).
  • They serve as alternative pathways during venous sinus thrombosis.
  • E.g., Ophthalmic veins (superior/inferior) connect Facial vein ↔ Cavernous sinus (function as emissary veins)

Clinical Relevance:

  • The foramen ovale serves as a vital passageway not just for neural structures (mandibular nerve) but also for emissary veins that may allow infections (e.g., from dental abscesses or facial infections) to reach the cavernous sinus, leading to cavernous sinus thrombosis. Since these veins are valveless, the flow is bidirectional and can facilitate rapid intracranial spread of pathogens.
  • Facial vein → Emissary veins → Cavernous sinus
    Infection from "danger triangle of the face" (e.g. pimple near nose) can reach brain → Cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Thrombosis of Sigmoid Sinus:
    Secondary to mastoiditis; may spread to superior sagittal sinus if emissary veins are involved.
  • Surgical Note: During mastoid surgery, avoid injury to the mastoid emissary vein to prevent bleeding or air embolism.

choices.text: Physiological tremors are reduced during anxiety
The dynamic response of muscle spindle Ia sensory fibers helps dampen oscillations in the feedback loop regulating muscle length
Physiologic tremor is independent of central sources and is caused only by peripheral factors such as reflexes and motor unit firing rates
Sensitivity of muscle spindles to velocity of stretch exaggerates physiologic tremor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding physiologic tremor is TRUE?
questions.solution:
• Dynamic and static responses of muscle spindle afferents influence physiologic tremor.
  • Option b: Ia sensory fibers in muscle spindles respond dynamically to the velocity of stretch, providing a rapid phasic response. This helps stabilize muscle length and reduces oscillations, preventing excessive tremor.
  • Option a: Physiologic tremors are exaggerated during anxiety, fatigue, or drug toxicity. These factors increase the oscillations in the feedback loop, making the tremor more noticeable.
  • Option c: Physiologic tremor results from a combination of central factors (e.g., the inferior olive) and peripheral factors (e.g., motor unit firing rates, reflexes, and mechanical resonance). It is not solely dependent on peripheral mechanisms.
  • Option d: The sensitivity of muscle spindles to velocity of stretch actually helps dampen physiologic tremor by stabilizing muscle length through precise phasic responses. If this sensitivity were impaired, tremors would become more prominent.

questions.text: A patient with type II diabetes was able to lower her HbA 1 c value from 9.2% to 6.9%. This occurred because of a reduction of which one of the following processes?
questions.solution:
Blood Glucose that enters the RBC can form a covalent abduct with ε-amino groups of lysyl residues and the alpha amino group of the N terminal valines of hemoglobin B chains, a process referred to as glycation. Unlike Glycosylation, Glycation is not enzyme catalyzed.

The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5% is proportionate to blood glucose concentration. Since life span of an erythrocyte is typically 120 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 8-12 weeks.

Measurement of HbA1 therefore provides valuable information for management of diabetes Mellitus.

HbA1c represents hemoglobin that has undergone non-enzymatic Glycation.

Non-enzymatic Glycation is directly related to the concentration of glucose in the blood. High blood glucose levels (as in uncontrolled diabetes) result in more Glycation and thus a higher HbA1c value. Conversely, improved glucose control reduces Glycation and lowers HbA1c levels.

Option A) Enzymatic oxidation: This does not describe the Glycation process of hemoglobin.

Option B) Non-enzymatic Glycosylation: While similar sounding, the term "Glycosylation" typically refers to enzyme-mediated addition of sugar moieties to proteins.

Option C) Enzymatic Glycosylation: As noted, Glycosylation is enzyme-mediated, unlike the non-enzymatic Glycation that forms HbA1c.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and difficulty swallowing. Imaging studies reveal a thickened stomach wall. Biopsy of the stomach wall shows a diffuse infiltrate of malignant cells, with a desmoplastic reaction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Adenocarcinoma of the stomach: Adenocarcinoma of the stomach is a common malignancy of the stomach, but it typically presents as a localized mass rather than a diffuse infiltrate.
  • Lymphoma of the stomach: Lymphoma of the stomach is a rare malignancy of the stomach, but it can present with a diffuse infiltrate.
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST): GIST is a rare malignancy of the stomach, but it typically presents as a localized mass rather than a diffuse infiltrate.
  • Linitis plastica: Linitis plastica is a type of gastric cancer characterized by a diffuse infiltrate of malignant cells, with a desmoplastic reaction, leading to a thickened and rigid stomach wall.

Key Takeaways

  • Linitis plastica is a rare and aggressive type of gastric cancer.
  • Linitis plastica is often associated with a poor prognosis due to its aggressive nature and difficulty in treatment.
  • Linitis plastica can be difficult to diagnose due to its non-specific symptoms and imaging findings, and often requires biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Which dermatophyte species is most commonly responsible for causing Tinea imbricata?
questions.solution:
Tinea imbricata is primarily caused by Trichophyton concentricum, a dermatophyte species responsible for the ring-like scaly lesions associated with this condition.

Key Takeaway: Tinea imbricata is specifically linked to T. concentricum.

Other options

A) Trichophyton mentagrophytes - A common dermatophytes that is found anywhere

B) Epidermophyton floccosum - Associated with T.cruris, T.pedis

D) Microsporum gypseum - Associated with Favus

questions.text: A 50 year old obese man recently diagnosed with vasospastic angina started a treatment with nifedipine. The drug has a volume of distribution (Vd) of about 55 L in a 70-kg person, but in this obese patient, the Vd turned out to be 110 L. The standard loading dose of nifedipine for a patient weighing 70 kg is 30 mg. Which of the following should be the therapeutic loading dose administered to this patient (in mg) in order to achieve the same target concentration?
questions.solution:
The dose of a drug can be calculated using the equation

  • Loading Dose = (Target plasma concerntration of Drug) * Vd / F
  • *Vd is volume of distribution
  • F = Bioavailability (100% here)
  • The loading dose is equal to the desired drug concentration times the volume of distribution divided by bioavailability.
  • Since the drug is administered intravenously, bioavailability is 100%.

Because the Vd of the obese patient is twice the Vd of a normal-weight person, the dose must be doubled to 60 mg to achieve the same plasma concent ration.

Key Takeaway

  • Loading dose: It is mainly used for drugs having long t½ and large volume of distribution. It is given to load (saturate) the tissue stores. So it is mainly dependent on Vd.
  • Loading dose = Vd × Target plasma concentration

[Dosing rate]

questions.text: "La facies sympathique" is an expression used in hanging to describe
questions.solution:
The term "La facies sympathique" refers to the asymmetrical appearance of the face in cases of hanging due to compression of the sympathetic cervical chain by the ligature. This phenomenon is marked by dilation of the pupil on the side opposite to the knot of the ligature.

Mechanism:

During hanging, the ligature compresses various anatomical structures in the neck, including blood vessels, nerves, and soft tissues.

If the sympathetic chain on one side of the neck is compressed (usually on the side where the knot of the ligature is placed), the opposite side experiences unopposed sympathetic activity, leading to dilation of the pupil (mydriasis) on the side opposite to the knot.

This condition occurs because the compression disrupts normal neural transmission along the sympathetic chain, causing asymmetry in sympathetic tone.

This phenomenon is particularly noted in forensic examinations of hanging victims.

Rule Out:

(a) Bilateral dilatation of pupils:

Bilateral dilation of pupils can occur in cases of asphyxia or central nervous system hypoxia, but it is not specific to hanging. "La facies sympathique" describes an asymmetrical change, not a bilateral phenomenon.

(b) Bilateral constriction of pupils:

Bilateral pupil constriction (miosis) may occur in opioid poisoning or other conditions affecting the parasympathetic nervous system. It is not associated with "La facies sympathique" in hanging.

(c) Dilated pupil on the side of the knot:

Dilation on the side of the knot does not occur because this is the side where the sympathetic chain is compressed. Compression results in loss of sympathetic tone on the same side, which would more likely cause pupil constriction (miosis) rather than dilation.

Key Takeaways:

"La facies sympathique" is an important forensic finding in hanging and indicates dilation of the pupil on the opposite side of the ligature knot due to compression of the cervical sympathetic chain.

Sympathetic nervous system compression leads to asymmetrical autonomic responses, aiding forensic pathologists in determining the direction and position of the ligature during hanging.

Differentiating symmetrical versus asymmetrical pupil changes provides critical insights into the underlying mechanisms of injury.

In forensic practice, understanding terms like "La facies sympathique" is essential for identifying hanging as a cause of death and the associated mechanisms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of Hill's criteria for establishing causation?
questions.solution:
Hill's criteria:

  1. Temporal association - Strongest criteria
  2. Strength of association
  3. Specificity of the association - Weakest criteria
  4. Consistency of the association

questions.text:
Patient with history of ear discharge and on otoscopic examination perforation seen in anterior Inferior segment of tympanic membrane. (ENT,1)
Comment on Rinne's Finding in this case:
questions.solution:
• Rinne's Test compares air conduction (AC) vs bone conduction (BC).
    • Rinne Positive = AC > BC (normal or sensorineural hearing loss)
    • Rinne Negative = BC > AC (seen in conductive hearing loss)

So, in tympanic membrane perforation with CHL, Rinne's test is negative.

questions.text: The aortic sinus that does NOT give rise to any coronary artery is
questions.solution:
The aortic sinuses, also known as the sinuses of Valsalva, are three dilatations at the root of the aorta, just above the aortic valve.

  • d. Posterior aortic sinus (Correct): Also called the non-coronary sinus, it does not give rise to any coronary artery. It lies posteriorly and does not contribute to the coronary circulation.
  • a. Left anterior aortic sinus: Incorrect terminology. There is no such sinus in existence.
  • b. Left posterior aortic sinus: Incorrect. The left posterior aortic sinus gives origin to the left coronary artery.
  • c. Right anterior aortic sinus: Incorrect. This refers to the right aortic sinus, which gives rise to the right coronary artery.

Simplified version:

Right coronary artery takes origin from the anterior (right coronary) aortic sinus of the ascending aorta, and left coronary artery takes origin from the left posterior (left coronary) aortic sinus of the ascending aorta, just above the aortic semilunar valve.

These aortic sinuses are located just above the semilunar cusps of the aortic valve, and their anatomical bulging prevents the valve cusps from adhering to the vessel wall, ensuring proper closure during diastole. During diastole, recoil of blood closes the valve and perfuses coronary arteries located in sinuses.

Embryologically, pulmonary valve has anterior, right and left cusps whereas aortic valve has posterior, right and left cusps. Thus the left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus, the right coronary artery from the right aortic sinus and no artery arises from the posterior aortic sinus (non-coronary sinus).

A detailed version, as given by most textbooks:

The positions of cusps of pulmonary valves are: (a) right anterior, (b) left anterior, and (c) posterior. The aortic sinuses are also named accordingly, i.e., right posterior aortic sinus, left posterior aortic sinus, and anterior aortic sinus. The right coronary artery arises from anterior aortic sinus and left coronary from left posterior aortic sinus.

Since no coronary artery arises from right posterior aortic sinus, it is referred to by some anatomists as non-coronary sinus.

Clinical Anatomy:

  • The three aortic sinuses of Valsalva are:
    • Right aortic sinus → Gives rise to the right coronary artery
    • Left aortic sinus → Gives rise to the left coronary artery
    • Posterior aortic sinus → Non-coronary sinus (does not give rise to a coronary artery)
  • Clinical Relevance: In conditions such as aortic dissection or sinus of Valsalva aneurysm, involvement of these sinuses can affect coronary blood supply. Non-coronary sinus involvement is less likely to cause ischemia unless it distorts aortic valve function.

questions.text: The external intercostal muscles of ribs help in inspiration. The bucket handle movement helps to increase following diameter of the thoracic cage by
questions.solution:
• Option c: The transverse diameter is increased by the bucket-handle movement, which occurs as the middle and lower ribs (ribs 7-10) move laterally during inspiration.
    This movement resembles the action of lifting the handle of a bucket, expanding the chest laterally. The external intercostal muscles play a key role in this action by elevating the ribs.
  • Option a: The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the thoracic cage increases during inspiration due to the pump-handle movement of the ribs.
    In this movement, the upper ribs (mainly ribs 2-6) elevate, pushing the sternum outward.
  • Option b: The vertical diameter of the thoracic cavity is increased by the contraction of the diaphragm, which flattens and moves downward during inspiration.
  • Option d: While both the AP diameter and the transverse diameter increase during inspiration, the bucket-handle movement specifically increases the transverse diameter, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Mutation in Gene coding for specific protein responsible for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is
questions.solution:
Dystrophin is of particular biomedical interest. Mutations in the gene that encodes it play a causative role in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Becker muscular dystrophy and have been implicated in dilated cardiomyopathy.

In case of Becker muscular dystrophy there is decrease in quantity of dystrophin

Dystrophin bridges the actine cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix at the interior face of the plasma membrane. Formation of this link is necessary for assembly of the synaptic junction. Duchenne muscular dystrophy appears to result from the inability of dystrophin to support formation of functionally competent synaptic junctions.

It is a peripheral membrane protein, not a transmembrane protein, and therefore does not bind hormones or neurotransmitters.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the origin of the coeliac trunk
questions.solution:
• Coeliac trunk arises from the anterior aspect of the abdominal aorta, immediately below the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm.
  • The aortic hiatus lies at the level of T12, and the coeliac trunk originates just inferior to this point, making the lower border of T12 the most precise vertebral level.
  • The origin of the coeliac trunk is most accurately localized to the transition zone between the T12 and L1 vertebrae, frequently corresponding to the level of the T12/L1 intervertebral disc. Evaluating the provided multiple-choice options within this context, the Lower border of the T12 vertebra (Option b) emerges as the most precise description representing the typical anatomical origin point.
  • The celiac trunk is a crucial vessel that supplies the foregut (stomach, liver, spleen, pancreas, and proximal duodenum).
  • The celiac trunk typically trifurcates into the left gastric, splenic, and common hepatic arteries.

Clinical Anatomy:

The position of the coeliac trunk at the lower border of T12 places it in proximity to the median arcuate ligament of the diaphragm and in the context of median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS), where abnormal compression of the coeliac trunk can occur.

choices.text: It is the point at which the voluntary breathing is not inhibited
Breathing 100% oxygen before breath holding delays breaking point
After breath holding, inhalation of gas mixture of low O2 and high CO2, reduces breath holding time

questions.text: True about breaking point is
questions.solution:
• Respiratory activity is controlled voluntarily and involuntary also.
  • Breath holding is possible voluntarily for some time after that at one-point voluntary control can no longer hold the breath. It is known as the breaking point.
  • Option b: Breathing pure oxygen before holding your breath increases the PO2 in the blood.
    This delays the buildup of CO2 and slows the drop in arterial oxygen levels, extending the time before the breaking point is reached.
  • Option a: The breaking point refers to the moment when a person is forced to resume breathing after holding their breath, regardless of voluntary control.
    At the breaking point, involuntary breathing efforts override voluntary inhibition due to the buildup of carbon dioxide (CO2) and/or depletion of oxygen (O2) in the blood.
  • Option c: Persons who hold their breath as long as possible and then breathe a gas mixture low in O2 and high in CO2 can hold their breath for an additional 20s or more.
  • Option d: Option b is a true statement, so "None of the above" is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Hepatocellular adenoma (HCA) is a rare, benign liver tumor. Which of the following molecular pathways is commonly mutated in HCA?
questions.solution:
A) Wnt/β-catenin pathway: Mutations in the Wnt/β-catenin pathway are commonly found in hepatocellular adenoma.

  • Beta catenin mutated hepatocellular adenoma (HA-B): beta catenin gene activating mutations (exon 7 - 8 and exon 3), resultant stabilization of beta catenin protein and increased or nontransient activation of Wnt / beta catenin signaling pathway.

B) PI3K/AKT pathway: While mutations in the PI3K/AKT pathway can occur in liver tumors, they are not as commonly associated with hepatocellular adenoma.

C) MAPK/ERK pathway: Mutations in the MAPK/ERK pathway can occur in liver tumors, but they are not as commonly associated with hepatocellular adenoma.

D) All of the above: While mutations in multiple pathways can occur in liver tumors, the Wnt/β-catenin pathway is most commonly associated with hepatocellular adenoma.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Hepatocellular adenoma is a rare, benign liver tumor that typically occurs in young women.
  2. Mutations in the Wnt/β-catenin pathway are commonly found in hepatocellular adenoma.

questions.text: Which of the following Aspergillus species is commonly associated with sinus infections, especially in hospital settings?
questions.solution:
Both option A and B are correct answers. Option A > B

Explanation and Key Points:

  • A. flumigatus and A. flavus are associated with both sinusitis and cutaneous infections, often in hospital settings due to its resistance to some environmental conditions
  • Beta 1,3 glucan testing is done for - 'CAP' - Invasive candidiasis, Invasive aspergillosis, Pneumocystis jirovecii
  • Galactomannan testing can be done for invasive aspergillosis

Other options

(C) Aspergillus niger primarily causes otitis externa and can cause pulmonary infections in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: During a phase 1 clinical trial, four different oral dosage forms of the same dose of a drug were administered to a healthy volunteer on four separate occasions. The plasma concentration-time curves are plotted below. Which of the following features best explains why formulation W produces the largest plasma concentration-time curve of the drug?
questions.solution:
• The amount of drug reaching the portal circulation after oral administration can be strongly influenced by the dosage formulation.
  • Because only single molecules of the drug can pass through the gut wall, the drug must be in solution in order to enter the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • For example, a tablet must be disintegrated and dissolved before reaching the portal circulation.
  • The efficiency of this process depends on several factors, including the way the tablet is manufactured and the excipients used.
  • Because in this case the same dose of the drug was administered, the concentration of the drug in the portal vein will be directly proportional to the oral bioavailability of the different formulations, which is indicated by the different AUCs depicted in the figure.

Bioavailability

  • It is the fraction of administered drug that reaches the systemic circulation in the unchanged form.
  • When we administer a drug orally, first it is absorbed into the portal circulation and reaches the liver.
  • Here, some of the drug may be metabolized (first pass metabolism or pre-systemic metabolism) and rest of the drug reaches the systemic circulation.
  • Thus, absorption and first pass metabolism are two important determinants of bioavailability.

By i.v. route, bioavailability is 100%.

  • Bioavailability can be calculated by comparing the AUC (area under plasma concentration time curve) for i.v. route and for that particular route.
  • AUC tells about the extent of absorption of the drug.
  • Tmax tells about the time to reach maximum concentration, i.e. rate of absorption
  • Cmax is the maximum concentration of a drug that can be Obtained

Key takeaway

  • The concentration of the drug in the portal vein will be directly proportional to the oral bioavailability of the different formulations

[Bioavailability]

questions.text: Match the following plant poisons with their active principles
questions.solution:
Here's the correct matching of plant poisons with their active principles:

  1. Opium (A):
    • The active principle in opium is morphine (Option 2). Opium is derived from the Papaver somniferum plant and contains several alkaloids, including morphine, which is a potent narcotic analgesic.
  2. Nux vomica (B):
    • The active principles in Nux vomica are brucine and strychnine, with brucine being the most relevant here (Option 4). These alkaloids are toxic and cause convulsions and other severe symptoms.
  3. Datura (C):
    • The active principle in Datura is hyoscyamine (Option 3), a tropane alkaloid that has anticholinergic properties, leading to symptoms like delirium, hallucinations, and in extreme cases, death due to respiratory failure.
  4. Abrus precatorius (D):
    • The active principle in Abrus precatorius (known as the rosary pea) is abrine (Option 1). This toxin is highly poisonous and can cause severe symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and death if ingested.

Rule Out:

  • The other answer combinations involve incorrect pairings of plant poisons and their active principles. For example, Nux vomica should not be matched with hyoscyamine (which belongs to Datura) or abrine (which belongs to Abrus precatorius).

Key Takeaways:

  • Opium contains morphine.
  • Nux vomica contains brucine (and strychnine).
  • Datura contains hyoscyamine.
  • Abrus precatorius contains abrine.
  • Understanding the active principles of plant poisons is crucial for diagnosing and managing poisoning cases.

questions.text: A 70 year old lady with an alleged history of impact on head following fall on an ice slab presents to the ER after 4 days with symptoms of headache, nausea, excessive sleep and lethargy. CT scan showed a crescent shaped hyper density crossing the sutural lines. She died after 4 days. What is the finding in the depicted image?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described and the findings on the CT scan (crescent-shaped hyperdensity crossing the sutural lines) are indicative of a subdural hematoma (SDH). SDH typically occurs due to a venous bleed, often as a result of trauma (like a fall) that causes tearing of the bridging veins between the dura mater and the brain. This leads to the accumulation of blood in the subdural space, which is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid layer of the meninges.

Key features of SDH:

  • Crescent-shaped hyperdensity on CT scan, which is characteristic of SDH, especially if it crosses sutural lines.
  • Common in older adults due to brain atrophy, which increases the risk of bridging vein rupture.
  • The symptoms can develop days after the injury, as seen in this case (headache, nausea, lethargy).

Rule Out:

  1. EDH (Epidural Hematoma):
    • EDH usually presents as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdensity on a CT scan, which does not cross sutural lines. It is typically due to an arterial bleed, often resulting from trauma to the middle meningeal artery. EDH presents more acutely with loss of consciousness and a lucid interval.
  2. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage):
    • SAH presents with diffuse blood in the subarachnoid space, seen on CT as hyperdensity around the brain. It typically involves the cerebral sulci and does not present with a crescent-shaped pattern or cross sutural lines like SDH.
  3. ICH (Intracerebral Hemorrhage):
    • ICH involves bleeding within the brain parenchyma itself and is seen as a localized area of hyperdensity on CT. It does not have the characteristic crescent shape or cross sutural lines associated with SDH.

Key Takeaways:

  • Subdural hematoma (SDH) presents as a crescent-shaped hyperdensity on CT, often crossing sutural lines. It is associated with venous bleeding, typically from bridging veins.
  • Epidural hematoma (EDH) appears as biconvex hyperdensity and is usually arterial in origin.
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) have different CT appearances and do not present with the crescent-shaped pattern characteristic of SDH.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman from a rural area in Madhya Pradesh, belonging to a Below Poverty Line (BPL) household, is admitted to the district hospital for her first delivery. She is concerned about the financial burden of the delivery and inquiries about government programs for maternal and neonatal health. Under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), how much cash assistance will this woman receive as a mother package for institutional delivery?
questions.solution:
• Janani Suraksha yojna:- under national rural health mission, it integrates the benefit of cash assistance with institutional care during antenatal, delivery and immediate post-partum care. This benefit will be given to all women, both rural and urban, belonging to below poverty line household. It is based on states whether the states are low performing or high performing states. Low performing states (LPS) are (Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Orissa, Assam, Rajasthan)
  • Janani shishu Suraksha karyakram:- a new national initiative, to make available better health facilities for women and child. It provides following facilities:- FREE AMBULANCE to mother and child up-to 1 year of age, from home to hospital and back from hospital to home. Free treatment, drugs, investigations, operation, or blood expenses to mother during delivery and to child up-to 1 year. Free food to mother and 1 attendant during 3 days of hospital stay.
  • RMNCH+A:- stands for reproductive maternal neonatal child and adolescent health program. Its strategy is based on provision of comprehensive care through the five pillars, or thematic areas of reproductive, maternal, neonatal, child, and adolescent health, and is guided by central tenets of equity, universal care, entitlement and accountability. The plus within the strategy focuses on including adolescence for the first time as a distinct life stage.
  • Navjat shishu Suraksha karyakram (NSSK):- NSSK is a programme aimed to train health personnel in basic newborn care and resuscitation. It has been launched to address care at birth issue i.e. prevention of hypothermia, prevention of infection, early initiation of breast feeding and basic newborn resuscitation. The objective of the new initiative is to have a trained health person in basic newborn care and resuscitation unit at every delivery point.

questions.text: A patient of head injury suffered hearing loss. He has normal tympanic membrane with type Ad Tympanogram. How much conductive hearing loss is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Type Ad Tympanogram

  • Indicates a hypermobile tympanic membrane.
  • Most commonly due to:
    • Ossicular chain disruption (especially incudo-stapedial joint dislocation) after head trauma.
  • Middle ear pressure is normal, but compliance (mobility) is excessively high.

Normal Tympanic Membrane

  • Suggests no perforation, so trauma is likely affecting the ossicles inside the middle ear, not the TM itself.

Expected Hearing Loss

  • Ossicular chain disruption = maximum conductive hearing loss.
  • In pure conductive hearing loss (no cochlear involvement), the maximum CHL is typically around 60 dB.
  • 54 dB CHL suggests a severe conductive loss, consistent with ossicular dislocation or disruption due to head trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is NOT at the floor of the anatomical snuff box
questions.solution:
The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the dorsum of the hand, prominently visible when the thumb is extended.

Boundaries:

  • Medial (ulnar) boundary: Tendon of Extensor pollicis longus
  • Lateral (radial) boundary: Tendons of Extensor pollicis brevis and Abductor pollicis longus
  • Proximal boundary: Styloid process of radius
  • Floor: Mainly formed by the scaphoid and trapezium bones, with a contribution from the distal end of the radius and base of 1st metacarpal. 

Option Analysis:

  • a. Scaphoid:
    • Forms part of the floor; hence, incorrect choice.
  • b. Trapezoid:
    • Does NOT form the floor of the anatomical snuff box, making it the correct answer.
  • c. Radius:
    • The distal end of radius contributes to the proximal border; incorrect choice.
  • d. 1st Metacarpal:
    • Base of the 1st metacarpal forms the distal border; incorrect choice.

Clinical Relevance:

The anatomical snuffbox is clinically significant because it contains the radial artery, which is used to assess peripheral circulation. Tenderness in this region can indicate a scaphoid fracture, the most common carpal bone fracture, which is typically caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand. Delay in diagnosis and treatment can lead to avascular necrosis of the scaphoid bone due to its retrograde blood supply.

choices.text: In MEPP the size of quanta of acetylcholine released is proportional to Mg++ conc.
In MEPP the size of quanta of acetylcholine released is inversely related to Ca++ conc.
MEPP is a minute depolarizing potential in the form of small spike of nearly 0.5 mv amplitude.

questions.text: Miniature end plate potential (MEPP) is seen in skeletal muscles. Which of the following is true about it?
questions.solution:
• Option c: MEPP is a small, spontaneous depolarizing potential that occurs at the neuromuscular junction, typically with an amplitude of about 0.5 mV. It represents the response to the release of a single quantum (packet) of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal.
  • Option a & b: The size of MEPP (Miniature End Plate Potentials) is influenced by Ca²+ concentration, not Mg²+.
    • Calcium ions (Ca²+) play a crucial role in the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
    • Magnesium ions (Mg²+), on the other hand, primarily act as an antagonist to calcium ions, inhibiting acetylcholine release.
  • Option d: As options A and B are incorrect, so "all of the above" is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient presents to medicine outpatient department with new onset essential hypertension. He also has a history of renal stones and has experienced a few episodes of renal colic. Which of the following diuretic is the most appropriate to use in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Patient was having recurrent calcium stones because of idiopathic hypercalciuria.
  • Thiazide diuretics decrease excretion of calcium and thus can be used for idiopathic hypercalciuria.

Uses of Thiazide diuretics

  1. Edema

Thiazides may be used for mild to- moderate cases.

They act best in cardiac edema; are less effective in hepatic or renal edema.

Thiazides are powerless in the presence of renal failure, but metolazone may still act.

  1. Hypertension

Thiazides and related diuretics, especially chlorthalidone and indapamide are one of the first line drugs

  1. Diabetes insipidus

Thiazides decrease positive free water clearance and are the only drugs effective in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

  1. Hypercalciuria with recurrent calcium stones in the kidney.

Thiazides act by reducing Ca2+ excretion.

Option A: Loop diuretics stimulate tubular calcium excretion and can thus be used to treat hypercalcemia.

Option C & D: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and potassium sparing diuretics do not have a significant impact on net calcium balance.

Add the highlighted content

  • Key Takeaway

Thiazide diuretics area called as calcium sparing diuretics, they decrease excretion of calcium and thus can be used for idiopathic hypercalciuria.

[Hydrochlorothiazide]

questions.text: Most common cause of death due to drowning in cold water is:
questions.solution:
In cold water drowning, vagal inhibition is the most common cause of death. This occurs when the body is immersed in very cold water, which causes a sudden diving reflex. This reflex triggers a vagal response, leading to a slowed heart rate (bradycardia) and sometimes cardiac arrest. In cold water, this reflex can be intense and, in some cases, can lead to immediate loss of consciousness or death due to vagal inhibition, particularly in individuals who are not accustomed to cold water immersion.

Rule Out:

  1. Ventricular fibrillation:
    • Ventricular fibrillation can indeed occur as a result of drowning, but it is more commonly associated with electric shock or severe hypothermia rather than cold water drowning alone. In cold water drowning, vagal inhibition is a more immediate cause of death.
  2. Laryngeal spasm:
    • Laryngeal spasm is a protective reflex designed to prevent water from entering the lungs during drowning. While it can occur, it is not the most common cause of death. If laryngeal spasm persists for a long time, it may lead to asphyxia, but it typically resolves after the person loses consciousness and stops struggling.
  3. Asphyxia:
    • Asphyxia is a primary cause of death in most drowning cases. However, in cold water drowning, the body may initially respond with vagal inhibition before asphyxia becomes a major issue.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vagal inhibition is the most common cause of death in cold water drowning, due to the body's diving reflex.
  • Ventricular fibrillation, laryngeal spasm, and asphyxia are all factors that can contribute to death in drowning, but vagal inhibition is the primary cause in cold water immersion.

choices.text: Insert an intrauterine device (IUD) within 7 days of unprotected intercourse
Take one tablet of levonorgestrel 0.75 mg within 72 hours of unprotected sex, and the second tablet 12 hours after the first dose.
Take one oral contraceptive pill containing 50 mcg of ethinyl estradiol within 72 hours, and the same dose after 24 hours.
Take two oral contraceptive pills containing 30 or 35 mcg of ethinyl estradiol within 72 hours, and two tablets after 12 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is a correct use of emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
• Insert an IUD, within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.
  • One tablet of levonorgestrel 0.75 mg withing 72 hours of unprotected sex, and the second tablet 12 hours after 1st dose.
  • Two oral contraceptive pills containing 50 mcg of ethinyl estradiol within 72 hours after intercourse, and the same dose after 12 hours.
  • Four oral contraceptive pills containing 30 or 35 mcg of ethinyl estradiol within 72 hours and 4 tablets after 12 hours
  • This method of taking OCPs in high doses for emergency contraception is called as Yuzpe and Lancee method

questions.text: Identify which protein energy malnutrition are given in image below?
questions.solution:
• Kwashiorkor and marasmus are the two different forms of protein and energy malnutrition. The main cause of this form of malnutrition is inadequate protein intake and low concentration of essential amino acids.
  • Kwashiorkor: - is a severe form of undernutrition, which develops in individuals on diet with a low protein/energy ratio. The main symptoms of kwashiorkor are oedema, wasting, liver enlargement, hypoalbuminemia, steatosis and the possible depigmentation of skin and hair.
  • Marasmus: - is the other form of malnutrition, which is caused by inadequate intake of both protein and energy. It is a form of severe cachexia with weight loss as a result of wasting in infancy and childhood. The main symptoms of marasmus are severe wasting, with little or no oedema, minimal subcutaneous fat, severe muscle wasting and non-normal serum albumin levels.

questions.text: Third window phenomenon is a feature of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Normally, the inner ear has two "windows":

  • Oval window - where the stapes transmits sound vibrations
  • Round window - compensates for pressure changes in the cochlea

In SSCD, a dehiscence (bony defect) occurs in the superior semicircular canal, creating an abnormal third window.

  • This third window leads to abnormal shunting of sound energy, especially low-frequency sound.
  • Causes a paradoxical conductive hearing loss (CHL) - even though the middle ear is normal.
  • Vertigo or autophony may occur due to vestibular system hypersensitivity to sound or pressure.

questions.text: 60 years old male patient is under investigation for the peripheral vascular disease. On examination, doctor took pulsation against the calcaneus bone about 2 cm below and behind the medial malleolus. Which of the following artery was palpated in the patient by the doctor
questions.solution:
In the provided scenario, the doctor palpated the artery about 2 cm below and behind the medial malleolus. This specific location corresponds to the posterior tibial artery, which is commonly palpated in clinical practice to assess peripheral circulation, especially in patients suspected of peripheral vascular disease.

Explanation of each option:

  • (a) Anterior tibial artery:
    • Incorrect: The anterior tibial artery runs anteriorly and becomes superficial at the dorsum of the foot as the dorsalis pedis artery. It is palpated on the dorsum of the foot, lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, not behind the medial malleolus.
  • (b) Posterior tibial artery:
    • Correct: The posterior tibial artery is located just behind and slightly below the medial malleolus, making it easily palpable in this location. It is commonly used to check peripheral pulses in clinical examinations.
  • (c) Dorsalis pedis artery:
    • Incorrect: The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsum (top) of the foot, not near the medial malleolus. It is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery, palpated between the first and second metatarsal bones.
  • (d) Plantar artery:
    • Incorrect: The plantar arteries (medial and lateral) are branches of the posterior tibial artery and run on the sole of the foot. They are deep and not palpable at the described location.

Clinical Anatomy:

  • The posterior tibial artery is frequently palpated clinically to assess peripheral arterial circulation, especially in individuals with peripheral vascular disease or diabetes mellitus.
  • The artery lies between the tendons of the flexor digitorum longus and flexor hallucis longus muscles, covered by the flexor retinaculum.
  • Absence or diminished pulsation at the posterior tibial artery can indicate peripheral vascular disease or arterial occlusion.

choices.text: Activation of intrinsic pathway of clotting
Platelet activation on exposure to atmospheric oxygen
Activation of extrinsic pathway of clotting

questions.text: Blood collected in the test tube without anticoagulant clots due to
questions.solution:
• Option a: Intrinsic system of clotting is activated by activation of clotting factor no.XII
  • This activation, which is catalyzed by high-molecular-weight kininogen and kallikrein occurs
    • in vitro by exposing the blood to glass,
    • in vivo by collagen fibers underlying the endothelium.
  • Option b: Platelets are indeed activated during blood clotting, but their activation is not directly caused by exposure to oxygen.
  • Option c: The extrinsic system is triggered by the release of tissue thromboplastin (TPL), a protein-phospholipid mixture that activates factor VII.
  • Option d: Hemolysis refers to the rupture of red blood cells, releasing hemoglobin into the plasma. This process is unrelated to blood clotting and does not contribute to clot formation.
    • While hemolysis can occur due to mechanical trauma during blood collection, it is not the cause of clotting.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are composed of
questions.solution:
• Reticular fibres are primarily composed of type III collagen fibres.
  • Type III collagen fibres are thinner and form a fine meshwork that provides structural support (scaffolding) to various soft organs such as the liver, spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow. These fibres are often associated with the basement membrane and provide support to the parenchyma of the organs.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • Option a (Collagen fibres type I):
    Type I collagen is the most abundant type of collagen found in the human body and is associated primarily with providing tensile strength to tissues such as skin, tendons, ligaments, and bone. It is thicker and stronger than type III collagen and does not form the delicate mesh-like network characteristic of reticular fibres.
  • Option b (Collagen fibres type II):
    Type II collagen fibres are predominantly found in cartilage, including hyaline cartilage and elastic cartilage. They are specialized for providing resistance to intermittent pressure and are not involved in forming reticular fibre networks.
  • Option d (Collagen fibres type IV):
    Type IV collagen fibres form the main structural framework of basement membranes. These fibres form a supportive network but differ structurally and functionally from reticular fibres, which specifically involve type III collagen.

Clinical Anatomy (Brief):

Reticular fibres, composed of type III collagen, play a significant role in maintaining the architecture and support of soft, highly cellular organs. Their presence is vital in lymphoid organs like lymph nodes and spleen, allowing these organs to expand or contract with immune activity.

  • It is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vascular type), where mutations in collagen type III genes lead to fragile blood vessels and tissues.
  • Disorders like myelofibrosis show excessive reticulin deposition.

choices.text: It occurs due to mutation in KALIG1 gene found on X chromosome

questions.text: A 24-year-old male visited the physician for some medical problem. On evaluation doctor diagnosed him with Kallaman syndrome. True about it is
questions.solution:
• Option a: Kallmann syndrome is often caused by mutations in the KAL1 gene (also known as KALIG1), which is located on the X chromosome.
    • This gene encodes a protein critical for the migration of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons and olfactory neurons during embryogenesis.
    • Mutations lead to a failure in the development of these systems, resulting in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia/hyposmia.
  • Option b: Kallmann syndrome is characterized by anosmia or hyposmia (reduced or absent sense of smell) due to the failure of the olfactory bulbs to develop properly. Increased sense of smell (hyperosmia) is not associated with this condition.
  • Option c: Kallmann syndrome typically results in delayed or absent puberty due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This is caused by a deficiency of GnRH, leading to low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). It delays maturation of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Option d: While a) is true, b) and c) are incorrect, so "all of the above" cannot be correct.

choices.text: Maximum velocity of an enzyme reaction.
The substrate concentration at which reaction velocity is half of Vmax.
The amount of enzyme required for a reaction.
The effect of inhibitors on enzyme activity.

questions.text: The Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) represents
questions.solution:
The Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) is a fundamental concept in enzyme kinetics. It is defined as the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of the maximum velocity (Vmax).

Km provides a measure of the affinity of an enzyme for its substrate:

A low Km indicates high affinity (enzyme works efficiently at low substrate concentration).

A high Km indicates low affinity (enzyme requires a higher substrate concentration to achieve half-maximal velocity).

This constant is derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation:

V - Vmax [S] / Km + [S]

Where:

  • v: Reaction velocity
  • Vmax: Maximum reaction velocity
  • [S]: Substrate concentration
  • Km: Michaelis-Menten constant

Thus, Km is an indicator of substrate binding efficiency but does not represent Vmax, enzyme quantity, or effects of inhibitors directly.

Option A)  The maximum velocity (Vmax) is the highest reaction rate achieved by the enzyme when the substrate is present in saturating amounts. While Km is related to Vmax (it defines substrate concentration when velocity is half of Vmax), it does not directly represent Vmax itself

Option C) Km is a property of the enzyme-substrate interaction and does not depend on the enzyme concentration.

The amount of enzyme required for a reaction determines how quickly the reaction reaches its maximum velocity (Vmax) but does not define the substrate affinity (Km)

Option D) Km does not directly represent the effect of inhibitors. Instead, inhibitors can alter the apparent Km:

Competitive inhibitors increase Km (require more substrate to overcome inhibition).

Non-competitive inhibitors affect Vmax without altering Km.

questions.text: Which of the following deformity is shown in the given diagram
questions.solution:
The image clearly shows:

  • A protruding cystic sac through a vertebral defect.
  • The sac contains both the meninges and spinal cord (neural elements).
  • The neural tissue appears to be displaced into the sac → which is a hallmark feature of meningomyelocele.

Why Other Options are Incorrect:

b. Meningocele

  • Only the meninges and CSF herniate.
  • Spinal cord remains in place.
  • No neural tissue in the sac - not the case here.

c. Syringomyelocoele

  • Very rare; involves a syrinx (fluid-filled cavity) in the spinal cord that also herniates.
  • Not typically visualized as a protruding cyst containing neural tissue + syrinx in this fashion.

d. Myelocoele

  • Spinal cord remains open on the surface.
  • Neural folds fail to fuse - usually without skin or sac covering, and open neural plate is exposed.
  • Not what is seen in this image.

Clinical Anatomy Insight:

  • Meningomyelocele is a severe form of spina bifida cystica.
  • Often associated with Arnold-Chiari II malformation, hydrocephalus, and neurological deficits (e.g., lower limb weakness, bladder/bowel incontinence).
  • Requires early neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following gastrointestinal peptide decreases the motility and secretion of small intestine?
questions.solution:
• Option a: The peptide YY It inhibits gastric acid secretion and motility. Its release is stimulated by fat. It slows down the digestive process to allow better nutrient absorption.
  • Option b: Substance P is a neuropeptide found in the gastrointestinal tract and nervous system.
  • It stimulates smooth muscle contraction and increases motility in the gastrointestinal tract. It promotes secretions like mucus in the gut
  • Option c: Motilin is secreted by M-cells in the small intestine during fasting.
    • It initiates the migrating motor complex (MMC), a pattern of motility that clears undigested food and bacteria from the stomach and small intestine during fasting. It has no significant effect on secretion. It is partially correct.
  • Option d: CCK is secreted by the I-cells of the duodenum and jejunum in response to fat and protein in the meal.
    • It stimulates the contraction of the gallbladder and relaxes the sphincter of Oddi to release bile. It promotes the secretion of pancreatic enzymes for digestion

questions.text: A 8year old boy presented with fever, pallor, fatigue and breathlessness. On examination, Icterus is present. Blood Investigations includes Hb - 8 gm/dl, S. total bilirubin - 6.9 mg/dl, Direct Bilirubin - 1.6 mg/dl and high LDH level. Patient had recurrent history of Jaundice in past. What are the possible causes of above condition
questions.solution:
As per given case scenario, presence of Icterus,low Hb level, high unconjugated bilirubin and LDH level is suggestive of Hemolytic - Prehepatic Jaundice. Most suitable answer from given option is G- 6 PD Deficiency as child also have previous recurrent history of Jaundice.


Option B) Chronic hepatitis usually presents with chronic liver damage, fatigue, jaundice, and altered liver enzymes (ALT/AST), not isolated hemolysis or recurrent episodes of jaundice. The direct bilirubin level would typically be more significantly elevated.

Option C) Acute pancreatitis presents with severe abdominal pain, elevated serum amylase/lipase, and systemic inflammatory signs. Jaundice may occur if the bile duct is obstructed but not due to hemolysis.

Option D) Drug-Induced: While certain drugs can cause hemolysis, G6PD deficiency is the underlying predisposition. Without G6PD deficiency, drug-induced hemolysis is less likely to cause recurrent jaundice.

choices.text: Hepcidin increases iron absorption by promoting ferroportion activity.
Hepcidin reduces serum iron levels by inhibiting ferroportion activity.
Hepcidin stimulates iron release from macrophages and hepatocytes.
Hepcidin directly binds to transferrin to regulate iron transport.

questions.text: Hepcidin is a key regulator of iron metabolism. Which of the following statements correctly describes its role?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin Function:Hepcidin is a hormone produced by the liver and is the central regulator of systemic iron homeostasis. It controls iron availability by regulating the function of ferroportin, the only known cellular iron exporter located on the surface of enterocytes (intestinal iron absorptive cells), macrophages (iron storage cells), and hepatocytes.

Mechanism:Hepcidin binds to ferroportin, causing its internalization and degradation.This inhibits iron export from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes, reducing iron absorption and release into the bloodstream.

Outcome: Serum iron levels decrease when hepcidin levels are high (e.g., during inflammation or iron overload).Hepcidin levels are suppressed in conditions like iron deficiency or increased erythropoietic activity, leading to increased iron absorption and release.

Option A) Incorrect: Hepcidin decreases ferroportin activity, reducing iron absorption.

Option C) Incorrect: Hepcidin inhibits iron release from macrophages and hepatocytes.

Option D) Incorrect: Hepcidin does not bind transferrin; it regulates ferroportion directly

Hepcidin Expression is influenced by Iron level, Erythropoiesis, Inflammation and Hypoxia.

Liver cells monitor iron levels using one of two “iron-sensing complexes” consisting of a homo dimer of either TfR1 and TfR2 bound to a third trans membrane protein, HFE.

  • HFE protein is a major histocompatibility (MHC) class 1-like molecule that binds β2-microglobulin (a component of class I MHC molecules, and, normally, TfR1.
  • TfR1 also binds the iron-bound form of transferrin (Tf-Fe), whose binding site overlaps with that for HFE. When iron is abundant and TfFe levels are high, the latter displaces HFE from TfR1. The displaced HFE protein then binds to TfR2, forming a complex that can be further stabilized by association with Tf-Fe. Formation of the HFE-TfR2 complex triggers an intracellular signaling cascade that activates expression of HAMP, the gene encoding hepcidin. It has been observed that mutations in the gene encoding HFE protein are commonly encountered in persons suffering from hereditary hemochromatosis.

Binding of cytokines such as interleukin 6 (IL-6) to their cell surface receptor activates expression of the gene encoding hepcidin via the JAK-STAT (Janus kinase-signal transducer and activator of transcription) pathway leading to anemia of chronic inflammation.

Hepcidin expression decreases during hypoxia or β-thalassemia.

The former is mediated by erythropoietin, whose synthesis is controlled by hypoxia-inducible transcription factors 1 and 2 (HIF-1 and HIF-2). In β-thalassemia, the expression of hepcidin is inhibited by growth differentiation factor 15 (GDF15) and twisted gastrulation 1 (TWSG1), which are secreted by erythroblasts.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with diarrhea, hematuria, and acute kidney injury. Renal biopsy is performed, and the histological findings are consistent with Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS). Which of the following is the most characteristic histological feature of HUS?
questions.solution:
A) Glomerular crescent formation: Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), not HUS.

B) Arteriolonephrosclerosis: Arteriolonephrosclerosis is a characteristic feature of hypertensive nephrosclerosis, not HUS.

C) Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA): TMA is the most characteristic histological feature of HUS, characterized by the formation of thrombi in the small blood vessels of the kidneys, leading to ischemic damage and acute kidney injury.

In TMA, there is a triad of renal injury, anemia and thrombocytopenia

D) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN): MPGN is a type of glomerulonephritis characterized by the deposition of immune complexes and the proliferation of mesangial cells, not HUS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is a pathologic term used to describe thrombi within microvasculature; TMA is clinically characterized by ischemic organ injury, particularly acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA).
  • TMA is a heterogeneous disease that is classically seen in hemolytic uremic syndrome and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura but can also be seen in a variety of clinical settings including severe hypertension, scleroderma renal crisis and preeclampsia / eclampsia, among others.
  • Classic / typical hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is an infection mediated process caused by Shiga toxin producing bacteria most commonly Escherichia coliO157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae; numerous other infections have also been associated with TMA
  • Atypical HUS is due to an inherited or acquired abnormality in complement proteins causing dysregulation of the alternative pathway.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency of enzyme responsible for above clinical signs showing Black discoloration of urine sample and ochronosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation Deficiency of Homogentisate Oxidase require for conversion of Homogentisate to Maleyacetoacetate leads to Alkaptonuria. In this condition, presence of Homogentiase in urine sample, gets oxidized on exposure of air which turns urine darkens.

Other signs & symptoms seen in alkaptonuria later in disease progression includes Arthritis, Tissue Pigmentation also known as ochronosis due to oxidation of homogentisate to benzoquinone acetate, which polymerizes and binds to connective tissue. This is inborn error of Amino Acid metabolism - Tyrosine.

Other option including Option A, Option B and option D have been involved in conditions like Tyrosinemia, Phenylketonuria as mentioned in below table.
