choices.text: Classical seminoma-like large cells with prominent nucleoli
Mixture of three cell populations with different sizes
Spindle-shaped cells with high mitotic activity

questions.text: Which of the following histologic features is MOST characteristic of spermatocytic tumor?
questions.solution:
A) Uniform small lymphocyte-like cells

  • Describes typical small cell populations
  • Not specific to spermatocytic seminoma
  • Lacks the distinctive heterogeneous cell pattern

B) Classical seminoma-like large cells with prominent nucleoli

  • Represents typical seminoma morphology
  • Spermatocytic seminoma has a unique cellular composition
  • Lacks the characteristic multi-population feature
  • Not associated with Germ cell neoplasia in situ

C) Mixture of three cell populations with different sizes

  • Hallmark histologic feature of spermatocytic seminoma
  • Includes:
    1. Small mature lymphocyte-like cells
    2. Medium-sized intermediate cells
    3. Large cells with bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Represents different stages of spermatocytic differentiation
  • Helps distinguish from classical seminoma
  • Spireme chromatin is a characterically present

D) Spindle-shaped cells with high mitotic activity

  • Suggests sarcomatoid transformation
  • Not typical of primary spermatocytic seminoma
  • High mitotic activity can occur but is not the defining feature

Key Takeaways:

  1. Unique Histologic Characteristics:
    • Trimodal cell population
    • Distinct from classical seminoma
    • Rare variant representing <1% of testicular tumors
  2. Cellular Composition:
    • Small cells: Resemble lymphocytes
    • Medium cells: Intermediate size
    • Large cells: Bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei
  3. Clinical Significance:
    • Generally less aggressive
    • Lower metastatic potential
    • Better prognosis compared to classical seminoma
  4. Age Distribution:
    • Typically occurs in older men (50-60 years)
    • Different from classical seminoma (younger patients)
  5. Diagnostic Importance:
    • Requires careful microscopic examination
    • Recognition of three-cell population is crucial
    • Immunohistochemistry can aid differentiation

Most common benign/ indolent tumor of the testis in the elderlySpermatocytic tumor

Most common malignant tumor of the testis in the elderlyDLBCL

questions.text: Which technique is not used for paternity testing?
questions.solution:
The Western blot technique is not suitable for paternity testing because it detects proteins, not DNA. Paternity testing requires the analysis of DNA to identify inherited genetic markers. Since the Western blot focuses on analyzing the presence, size, and expression of proteins, it cannot provide the genetic information necessary for determining biological relationships.

  1. Analyzes Proteins: Western blot detects specific proteins in a sample using antibodies. It does not work with DNA, which is the molecular basis for paternity testing.
  2. No Hereditary Markers: Proteins do not directly reflect inheritance patterns as DNA does. Genetic inheritance is determined by analyzing DNA sequences or markers (e.g., STRs, SNPs).
  3. Lack of Specificity for Paternity: Western blotting cannot distinguish between individuals based on their protein profiles since these are not as unique or inherited like DNA markers.

Mnemonic - SNOW DROP

(Southern Blot - DNA

Northern Blot - RNA

Western Blot - Proteins)

Suitable Techniques for Paternity Testing:

  • DNA-Based Methods:
    • STR Analysis (PCR-based).
    • SNP Analysis.
    • RFLP or Southern Blot (historical techniques)
    • Southern Blot Technique (Not used nowadays)

1. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)-Based Techniques

PCR is the most widely used method due to its sensitivity, speed, and accuracy.

a. Short Tandem Repeat (STR) Analysis

  • How it works: STRs are repeating sequences of 2-6 base pairs in DNA that are highly polymorphic. By comparing STR markers between the child and the alleged parent, paternity can be determined.
  • Advantages:
    • Highly accurate.
    • Requires a small DNA sample.
    • Automated and rapid.

b. Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) Testing

  • How it works: SNPs are single base-pair variations in DNA. Panels of SNP markers are analyzed to determine inheritance patterns.
  • Advantages:Useful when DNA is degraded.Requires less DNA than STR analysis.Can provide additional ancestry information.

2. Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP)

  • How it works: DNA is digested with restriction enzymes to generate fragments of varying lengths. These fragments are analyzed using electrophoresis, and patterns are compared between the child and the alleged parent.
  • Advantages: High accuracy when DNA is intact.

Limitations: Requires large amounts of high-quality DNA; labor-intensive.

3. Southern Blotting

  • How it works: Detects specific DNA sequences, such as VNTRs (Variable Number Tandem Repeats), using labeled probes. VNTR patterns from the child are compared to those of the mother and alleged father.
  • Advantages: Historically important for paternity testing.
  • Limitations: Labor-intensive, requires high-quality DNA, and has been largely replaced by PCR-based methods.

choices.text: Translocation involving the TMPRSS2 and ERG genes

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is diagnosed with prostate cancer. Which of the following genetic alterations is most commonly associated with prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
A) Mutation in the TP53 gene: Associated with Li Fraumeni- Here there is risk of development of brain tumors, breast tumors and acute myeloid leukemias

B) Deletion of the PTEN gene: Associated with Cowden syndrome- associated with breast, endometrium and thyroid

C) Amplification of the MYC gene: There are 3 types - C MYC, N MYC, L MYC. C MYC is significant in Burkitts lymphoma

D) Translocation involving the TMPRSS2 and ERG genes: This is the correct answer. Translocations involving the TMPRSS2 and ERG genes are the most common genetic alteration in prostate cancer, occurring in up to 50% of cases.

Key Takeaways

  1. Translocations involving the TMPRSS2 and ERG genes are the most common genetic alteration in prostate cancer.
  2. Understanding the genetic alterations that contribute to prostate cancer is critical for the development of effective therapies.

questions.text: In an experiment, neutrophils collected from peripheral blood are analyzed for a "burst" of oxygen consumption. This respiratory burst is an essential step for which of the following events in an acute inflammatory response?
questions.solution:
A) Attachment to endothelial cells: While neutrophils do attach to endothelial cells during the inflammatory response, this event is mediated by adhesion molecules such as selectins and integrins, and not by the respiratory burst.

B) The respiratory burst is a critical event in the acute inflammatory response, and it is essential for the generation of microbicidal activity.

  • During the respiratory burst, neutrophils undergo a rapid increase in oxygen consumption, which leads to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, and hydroxyl radicals.
  • These ROS are toxic to microorganisms and play a crucial role in the killing of bacteria and other pathogens by neutrophils.

C) Increased production in bone marrow: Myelopoiesis does not depend on generation of superoxide.

D) Opsonization of bacteria: Opsonization is the process by which antibodies or complement proteins bind to the surface of bacteria, making them more susceptible to phagocytosis. While opsonization is an important step in the inflammatory response, it is not directly related to the respiratory burst. C3b, IgG, Mannose binding lectins are some of the opsonins

Key Takeaway

  • The respiratory, or oxidative, burst of neutrophils generates reactive oxygen species (e.g., superoxide anion) that are important in destruction of engulfed bacteria.
  • This burst can be quantitated by flow cytometric analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is the most common cause of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)?
questions.solution:
A) Enterovirus 71: Although Enterovirus 71 is associated with more severe cases of HFMD, especially in East and Southeast Asia, it is not the most common cause globally.

B) Coxsackievirus A16: This is the most common cause of HFMD and is responsible for the majority of cases, presenting with typical symptoms like fever, vesicular rash, and ulcerations on the oral and pharyngeal mucosa.

C) Coxsackievirus A6: This strain can cause more severe manifestations of HFMD but is not as common as Coxsackievirus A16.

D) Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus is not typically associated with HFMD and causes different clinical manifestations (e.g., cold sores).

Key Takeaway:

  • Coxsackievirus A16 is the primary cause of HFMD, though other enteroviruses like Coxsackievirus A6, B(1-3 )and Enterovirus 71 can cause more severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following biological indicators (BI) is used to check the effectiveness of sterilization in ethylene oxide (ETO) sterilizers?
questions.solution:
• A) Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus stearothermophilus - These are the correct organism for Autoclave and gas plasma (hydrogen peroxide) sterilizers. It is not used for ethylene oxide sterilization.
  • B) Bacillus atrophaeus: This is the correct answer. Bacillus atrophaeus spores are used as the biological indicator in ethylene oxide (EO) sterilization and dry heat sterilization (hot air oven).
  • D) Geobacillus atrophaeus: This is not a standard name for a biological indicator organism. The correct organism for ethylene oxide sterilization is Bacillus atrophaeus.

Key Takeaways:

  • ETO is used for sterilising prepacked syringes, catgut sutures, respirators, heart lung machines, dental equipments
  • Bacillus atrophaeus is the standard biological indicator for ethylene oxide sterilization and dry heat sterilization.
  • Geobacillus stearothermophilus is used for Autoclave and gas plasma sterilization.
  • Biological indicators help confirm the effectiveness of sterilization by using highly resistant bacterial spores.

References:

  • CDC Guidelines for Sterilization and Infection Control.
  • Manual of Infection Prevention and Control, JIPMER.

choices.text: No fasciculations, no change in muscle strength

questions.text: A 47 year old man was admitted to the emergency department because of extreme muscle weakness, ptosis, diplopia, and difficulty in swallowing, speaking, and breathing. The man, recently diagnosed with severe myasthenia gravis, had been receiving neostigmine for the past 3 months. Which of the following responses to 2 mg of intravenous edrophonium would indicate a cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
• Patients with myasthenia gravis may present in the emergency with muscle weakness.
  • This could be because of the aggravation of their primary problem (myasthenic crisis) or due to the overdose of the drugs like neostigmine (cholinergic crisis).
  • The etiology of the two conditions is important to understand because in myasthenic crisis, there is deficiency of acetylcholine whereas in cholinergic crisis, there is excess of acetylcholine.
  • Edrophonium is an inhibitor of the enzyme acetylcholinestrase and thus, increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • The increased availability of ACh causes dramatic improvement in the symptoms of patients with myasthenic crisis.
  • In contrast, the symptoms of patients with cholinergic crisis worsen with edrophonium (because it further increases ACh in cholinergic crisis).
  • The drug, therefore, is useful to clinically differentiate the actual cause of muscle weakness in an emergency situation.
  • The reason for preferring edrophonium over other inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase is its short duration of action.
  • This may be desirable for patients presenting with cholinergic crisis as the worsening in their condition would be only for a short time.

In the question, cholinergic crisis is replaced with myasthenia gravis, the answer would be Option A- No fasciculations, increased muscle strength

Key Takeaway

  • Edrophonium is an inhibitor of the enzyme acetylcholinestrase and thus, increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, causing dramatic improvement in the symptoms of patients with myasthenic crisis.
  • Edrophonium can be used to distinguish between the two syndromes. In fact, in cases of cholinergic crisis, edrophonium administration will produce no relief or worsen the syndrome. (a decrease in muscle strength), whereas in cases of myasthenic crisis, the drug will improve the syndrome (an increase in muscle "strength").

questions.text: A 43 year old man with a long history of exertional angina was recently diagnosed with migraine. Which of the following antimigraine drugs would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Triptans are contraindicated in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease, because rare but serious adverse cardiac effects, including heart attacks, life-threatening disturbances of cardiac rhythm, and death, have been reported within a few hours of receiving one of these drugs.
  • The mechanism of this adverse effect is likely related to the vasoconstricting actions of these drugs.
  • Sumatriptan (subcutaneous) is the drug of choice for aborting acute attack of migraine.
  • All of these drugs can cause coronary vasospasm and are contraindicated in ischemic heart disease.
  • Triptans are also contra-indicated in following patients
    • Hypertension,
    • Epilepsy,
    • Pregnancy,
    • Liver and renal impairment.

Sumatriptan

  • It is the first selective 5-HT1D/1B receptor agonist
  • Advantages of Triptans over Ergot compounds:
    • Sumatriptan is effective and better tolerated than ergotamine.
    • It tends to suppress nausea and vomiting of migraine
    • The triptans have been found to suppress neurogenic inflammation of cranial vessels.
  • The antimigraine activity of sumatriptan has been ascribed to 5-HT1D/1B receptor mediated constriction of dilated cranial blood vessels, especially the arterio-venous shunts in the carotid artery, which express 5-HT1D/1B receptors.
  • The use of sumatriptan (or other triptans) should be restricted to treatment of acute attacks of moderate to severe migraine not responding to analgesics or their combinations.

Drug of choices (DOC) for Migraine

Option A, B & D: All of these drugs are used in the acute therapy and/or in prevention of migraine headache.

Key takeaway: Triptans are contraindicated in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease, because rare but serious adverse cardiac effects, including heart attacks, life-threatening disturbances of cardiac rhythm, and death, have been reported within a few hours of receiving one of these drugs.

Tag: Sumatriptan

questions.text: Mr. 'A' killed Mr. 'B' in a park. Mr. 'C' came to the court of Law as prosecution witness saying "I saw Mr. 'A' with the knife minutes before the incident". The evidence given by Mr. 'C' helps in the court to prove the crime as
questions.solution:
The evidence provided by Mr. C is indirect evidence because it does not directly prove that Mr. A killed Mr. B but instead provides circumstantial information that helps to establish the context of the crime. Mr. C's testimony that he saw Mr. A with a knife shortly before the incident is an important piece of evidence that may support the inference that Mr. A could have been involved in the killing, but it does not directly observe or describe the actual act of killing.

  • Indirect evidence (or circumstantial evidence) refers to evidence that requires inference to connect it to a conclusion about the fact in question.

Rule Out:

  1. Direct evidence:
    • Direct evidence would be a statement or testimony that directly proves a fact without the need for inference. For example, if Mr. C had testified, "I saw Mr. A kill Mr. B," that would be direct evidence.
  2. Hearsay evidence:
    • Hearsay evidence refers to statements made outside of the court that are being introduced to prove the truth of the matter asserted. In this case, Mr. C is testifying about something he personally observed, not something he heard from someone else, so it is not hearsay.
  3. Hostile evidence:
    • Hostile evidence refers to testimony from a witness who is opposing or reluctant to testify for the party who called them, often showing hostility or bias. Mr. C's testimony does not seem to indicate hostility, as he is providing relevant information about the incident.

Key Takeaways:

  • Indirect evidence helps establish the circumstances of a crime and requires inference to connect it to the fact in question.
  • Direct evidence directly proves a fact, such as witnessing the actual crime being committed.
  • Hearsay and hostile evidence have distinct definitions and do not apply in this scenario.

questions.text: A 23-year male patient was brought to the hospital with history of stove burst. Burns involving face & head with singeing of hair, neck, both arms and front of chest bilaterally noted. The percentage of burns is
questions.solution:
The Rule of Nines is a commonly used method to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns. It divides the body 11 parts, each part roughly represents 9% of body surface area burns; i.e., 11 x 9 = 99% plus 1% for perineum.

Head & neck, Upper limb and lower limb are further divided as follows.

Burns noted in this case,

Face & head = 7%

Neck = 2%

Both arms = 4 = 4 = 8%

Front of chest bilaterally = 9%

Total = 7 + 2 + 8 + 9 = 26%

Key Takeaways:

The Rule of Nines is an essential tool for estimating burn surface area, particularly in adults, and is critical for determining treatment needs such as fluid resuscitation.

Lund and Browder chart is best to estimate the total body surface area burns in both adults and children.

Accurate assessment of burn extent is critical for determining severity and guiding initial management.

Overestimating or underestimating burn percentage can significantly affect treatment outcomes, especially in fluid therapy calculations like the Parkland formula.

questions.text: AQI of Delhi has been increasing at an alarming rate. The government authorities have asked public health specialist to monitor the air pollution. All of the following are indicators except?
questions.solution:
Following are the indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulphur dioxide: - this gas is a major contaminant in many urban and industrial areas. Its concentration is estimated in all air pollution surveys.
  • Smoke or soiling index: - a known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by photoelectric meter. Smoke concentration is estimated and expressed as micrograms/cubic metres of air as an average level over a period of time.
  • Grit and dust measurement: - deposit gauges collect grit, dust and other solids. These are analysed monthly.
  • Coefficient of haze: - a factor used particularly in the USA in assessing the amount of smoke and other aerosols in air.
  • Air pollution index: - it is an arbitrary index which takes into account one or more pollutants as a measure of severity of pollution.

choices.text: Repeat direct laryngoscopy every hour to assess laryngeal oedema

questions.text: In a patient of acute epiglottitis, all of the following are part of management except:
questions.solution:
Acute epiglottitis (most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B) is a life-threatening emergency due to the risk of sudden airway obstruction.

Direct laryngoscopy is contraindicated in suspected epiglottitis unless airway is already secured or done in a controlled environment (like OR or ICU).

Repeated laryngoscopy every hour increases the risk of:

  • Laryngospasm
  • Increased edema
  • Trauma
  • Sudden airway collapse

Hence, it's not a part of routine management and is potentially dangerous.

Correct Management Includes:

  • Airway protection (Intubation if needed)
  • IV broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone)
  • IV corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone) to reduce edema
  • Minimal handling of the airway

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy has appeared listless during the past week. He exhibits irritability when his arms or legs are touched. In the past 2 days, large ecchymoses have appeared on the right thigh and left shoulder. CBC shows hemoglobin, 9.3 g/dL; hematocrit, 28.7%; MCV, 96 μm3; platelet count, 45,000/mm3; and WBC count, 13,990/mm3. Examination of the peripheral blood smear shows blasts that lack peroxidase positive granules, but contain PAS-positive aggregates and stain positively for deoxynucleotidyl transferase negative (TdT-). Flow cytometry shows the phenotype of blasts to be CD19+, CD3-. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: These findings are characteristic of a childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia of the precursor-B-cell type.

  • The rap­id expansion of the marrow caused by proliferation of blasts can lead to bone pain and tenderness. Features supporting an acute leukemia are anemia, thrombocytopenia, and the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood and bone marrow.
  • Anemia and thrombocytopenia result from suppression of normal hematopoiesis by the leukemic clone in the marrow.
  • The phenotype of CD19+, CD3−, is typical of pre-B cells.
  • TdT is a marker of early T-cell-type and B-cell-type lym­phoid cells
  • Age group - 1 to 10 years

B) An acute myelogenous leukemia is a disease of young to middle-aged adults, and there would be peroxidase-positive myeloblasts and phenotypic features of myeloid cells.

C) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a disease of older adults; patients have many small circulating mature B lymphocytes.

D) Chronic myelogenous leukemia is a disease of adults, and the WBC count is quite high; the peripheral blood contains some myeloblasts, but other stages of myeloid differentiation also are detected.

  • The presence of blasts that lack peroxidase-positive granules, which suggests that the blasts are of lymphoid origin.
  • The presence of PAS-positive aggregates, which is a characteristic feature of ALL.

Key Takeaway:

  • The blasts stain positively for TdT, which is a marker of lymphoblasts.
  • Flow cytometry shows the phenotype of blasts to be CD19+, CD3-, and sIg-, which is consistent with B-cell ALL.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old patient presents with fever, fatigue, and a stiff neck. CSF analysis reveals the following:
CSF pressure: 150 mm of water
Total leukocyte count: 350/mm3
Predominant cell type: Lymphocytes
Glucose: 55 mg/dL
Total proteins: 60 mg/dL Given the CSF analysis, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A) Pyogenic meningitis: Incorrect. Pyogenic meningitis usually presents with elevated CSF pressure, a markedly increased leukocyte count (100-10,000/mm³), predominantly neutrophils, and low glucose levels, which does not match the features in this case.
  • B) Tuberculous meningitis: Incorrect. While tuberculous meningitis shows lymphocytic predominance, it typically features moderately elevated protein levels (100-500 mg/dL), which is much higher than the 60 mg/dL seen in this case.
  • C) Viral meningitis: Correct. The CSF findings of lymphocytic predominance, normal glucose (55 mg/dL), and normal/slightly elevated protein levels (60 mg/dL) are consistent with viral meningitis, which is often caused by enteroviruses, mumps, or herpesviruses.
  • D) Fungal meningitis: Incorrect. Fungal meningitis typically shows lymphocytic predominance but also tends to have higher protein levels (100-500 mg/dL) and can show more chronic features, which are not indicated by the normal glucose and mild protein elevation in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • Viral meningitis commonly shows lymphocytic predominance, normal glucose, and moderate protein elevation in the CSF.
  • Pyogenic meningitis has high leukocyte counts, neutrophilic predominance, and low glucose.
  • Tuberculous meningitis is characterized by a moderate increase in proteins, lymphocytic predominance, and slightly decreased glucose.

questions.text: A 51-year old man was admitted to the hospital with an asthmatic attack. The man had been suffering from seasonal asthma for 1 year. On questioning, he reported that he took two aspirin tablets the previous evening for a headache. A diagnosis of drug hypersensitivity was made, an appropriate therapy was instituted, and later he was discharged from the hospital. Which of the following treatments would be most appropriate for his postdischarge therapy?
questions.solution:
• Leukotriene inhibitors and antagonists have demonstrated the important role of leukotrienes in aspirin-induced asthma.
  • Some asthmatic patients are very sensitive to aspirin as well as to all nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and even small doses can cause profound bronchoconstriction, flushing, and abdominal cramping.
  • The syndrome is not allergic in nature but seems to be related to the inhibition of cyclooxygenase, which most likely causes
    • A shift of arachidonic acid metabolism to the leukotriene pathway; leukot rienes are powerful bronchoconst ricting agents.
    • Decreased synthesis of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), which is an endogenous bronchodilator, very important in maintaining airway patency for most asthmatics
  • Leukotriene antagonists such as zafirlukast and montelukast are the drugs most frequently used for maintenance therapy in patients with aspirin induced asthma.

Option B & D: Systemic glucocorticoids and theophylline are used only in case of severe asthma that is resistant to other pharmacotherapies.

Option C: These drugs are used only by inhalation.

Key Takeaway:Leukotriene inhibitors and antagonists have demonstrated the important role of leukotrienes in aspirin-induced asthma.

Tag: Zafirlukast

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Definition of Suggilation:

Suggilation refers to postmortem lividity or hypostasis, which is the pooling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death due to gravity.

It appears as purplish-red discoloration on the skin and is often mistaken for bruising.

Mechanism of Formation:

After the heart stops pumping, blood settles in the lowest parts of the body.

This causes visible discoloration in areas that are not under pressure.

Key Features of Suggilation:

Begins 20-30 minutes after death and becomes fixed (non-blanching) after 8-12 hours.

The distribution of suggilation can help determine body position at the time of death.

Rule Out Explanation:

Option (a): Algor Mortis:

Algor mortis refers to the cooling of the body after death and does not involve visible discoloration of the skin.

Option (c): Putrefaction:

Putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues due to bacterial activity, often producing bloating, marbling, and a foul odor. It is a later stage of decomposition, not an immediate postmortem change like suggilation.

Option (d): Marbling:

Marbling is the greenish-black discoloration along veins due to decomposition and is seen in the later stages of putrefaction. It does not resemble the uniform, purplish-red patches of suggilation.

Key Takeaways:

Suggilation is a critical postmortem change used in forensic investigations to determine the time since death and the position of the body after death.

It differs from marbling, which is a putrefactive change, and from bruising, which occurs during life due to trauma.

Forensic distinctions between postmortem changes like suggilation, rigor mortis, and algor mortis are essential for accurate medicolegal evaluations.

The appearance and distribution of suggilation can provide clues about possible movement of the body postmortem.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with rapidly enlarging cervical lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss over the past month. A biopsy of the lymph node reveals large, pleomorphic B-cells with prominent nucleoli, and immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CD20 and CD10. The tumor cells are also negative for CD5 and CD23. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Follicular lymphoma typically presents with a more indolent course and is characterized by small, cleaved cells and a t(14;18) translocation, which is not seen in this case. It is also often CD10 positive, but CD5 and CD23 positivity would be expected in CLL, not DLBCL.

B) DLBCL is a common and aggressive lymphoma that presents with rapidly enlarging lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss (the "B symptoms"). The biopsy reveals large, pleomorphic B-cells with prominent nucleoli, and immunohistochemistry typically shows CD20 and CD10 positivity, which are features of DLBCL. The negative staining for CD5 and CD23 helps to rule out CLL or other small B-cell lymphomas.

C) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is typically characterized by small, mature B-cells in the peripheral blood and bone marrow. CLL usually has CD5 and CD23 positivity, which is not seen in this case. It also typically presents with indolent symptoms, unlike the aggressive presentation seen here.

D) Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive lymphoma with a characteristic "starry sky" appearance on histology due to macrophages clearing apoptotic tumor cells. It is associated with the t(8;14) translocation and is often EBV-associated, but the large pleomorphic cells in this case are more consistent with DLBCL. Positive for CD10, CD38

Key Takeaway: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is an aggressive lymphoma that commonly presents with rapidly enlarging lymph nodes, B symptoms, and pleomorphic B-cells. Immunohistochemistry showing positivity for CD20 and CD10, along with negativity for CD5 and CD23, supports the diagnosis of DLBCL.

choices.text: The presence of pili is a principal virulence factor that aids in adhesion and protects the bacterium from phagocytosis.
Neisseria gonorrhoeae produces a single type of porin protein that is associated with disseminated gonococcal infections.
Gonococcal infections are less likely to cause symptoms in females compared to males, with a higher rate of asymptomatic carriage.
Neisseria gonorrhoeae can only ferment glucose and not maltose or sucrose, which helps differentiate it from other Neisseria species.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Neisseria gonorrhoeae is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Correct. Pili are important virulence factors for adhesion and avoiding phagocytosis. (pili based typing)
  • Option B: Incorrect. N. gonorrhoeae produces two major types of porin proteins (PorB.1A and PorB.1B). PorB.1A is associated with both local and disseminated gonococcal infections.
  • Option C: Correct. Females often have asymptomatic carriage, making gonorrhea less symptomatic than in males. Can present as cervicitis in some cases
  • Option D: Correct. N. gonorrhoeae ferments only glucose, which helps differentiate it from other Neisseria species.

Key Takeaway: Neisseria gonorrhoeae produces two types of porin proteins, and misidentifying this could lead to confusion in diagnosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman has noted a nodule beneath the skin in her left groin since adolescence. On physical examination, the lesion has a 2-cm diameter and is nontender, soft, rubbery, and movable. Which of the following cell types is most likely to comprise this lesion?
questions.solution:
A) The clinical presentation of a soft, rubbery, and movable nodule in the groin area is consistent with a lipoma.

  • Lipomas are benign tumors composed of mature adipocytes (fat cells). They are typically soft, mobile, and painless, and can occur in various locations, including the groin area.
  • The characteristics of the lesion, such as its soft and rubbery texture, and its mobility, are all consistent with a lipoma.

B) Endothelial cells are involved in the formation of blood vessels and are not typically associated with soft tissue tumors like lipomas.

C) Fibroblasts are involved in the production of collagen and other connective tissue components, and are not typically associated with lipomas. Classic history of Herring bone

D) Skeletal muscle cells are involved in muscle contraction and are not typically associated with soft tissue tumors like lipomas. Rhabdotumors, typical history of strap cells, desmin, myogenin, myo D1

Key Takeaways

  • Benign tumor composed of mature adipocytes

Essential features

  • Most common soft tissue tumor
  • Mostly subcutaneous, < 5 cm
  • Radiologically, grossly and microscopically same as normal fat
  • In large (> 10 cm) and deep seated / retroperitoneal tumors, exclusion of MDM2amplification is required for diagnosis

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with AIDS presents with fever, productive cough, and consolidation seen in the right lower lobe on chest X-ray. His CD4 count is less than 55 cells/μL. Which pathogen is most likely responsible for his pneumonia?
questions.solution:
• (A) Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus is an opportunistic pathogen, it is less common in the context of severely immunocompromised patients with a very low CD4 count compared to Pneumocystis jiroveci. It can cause pneumonia but is not the most frequent cause in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts.
  • (B) Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia in the general population and even in immunocompromised patients (including HIV positive patients). The characterisitic consolidation in the radiograph points towards Streptococcus pnemoniae
  • (C) Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Mycoplasma pneumoniae typically causes mild pneumonia and is not a common cause of severe pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals with a very low CD4 count.
  • (D) Pneumocystis jiroveci: Pneumocystis jiroveci is a fungal pathogen that is a well-known cause of pneumonia (PCP) in patients with HIV/AIDS, particularly those with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL. However this is not the right answer because P. Jiroveci causes atypical pneumonia

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumocystis jiroveci is the most common cause of pneumonia in severely immunocompromised AIDS patients, especially those with CD4 counts below 200.
  • Clinical presentation includes subacute onset of fever, cough, and dyspnea.
  • Chest X-ray often shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates with a "ground-glass" appearance.
  • Other causes of pneumonia in AIDS patients include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae, but these are less common in this scenario.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has had an increasing number of subcutaneous nodules developing over the past 20 years. On physical examination the nodules range from 0.5 to 1.5 cm in size and are firm and nontender. She also has multiple cafe-au-lait spots on her skin. She now has pain in her posterior left thigh. MR imaging shows an 8-cm mass. A mutation encoding for which of the following proteins is most likely to be present in this woman?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of multiple subcutaneous nodules, café-au-lait spots, and a large mass in the posterior thigh is consistent with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

A) Actin is a protein involved in muscle contraction and is not associated with NF1.

B) NF1 is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene, which encodes for the protein neurofibromin. Neurofibromin is a tumor suppressor protein that regulates the activity of the RAS protein, which is involved in cell growth and division.

The clinical features of NF1 include:

  • Multiple café-au-lait spots
  • Multiple subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Plexiform neurofibromas (large, diffuse tumors)
  • Optic gliomas
  • Bone abnormalities

C) Caveolin is a protein involved in cell signaling and is not associated with NF1.

D) Dystrophin is a protein involved in muscle function and is associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Becker muscular dystrophy, but not NF1.

Key Takeaways

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene, which encodes for the protein neurofibromin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best choice for isolating fastidious bacteria that do not grow on standard blood agar?
questions.solution:
• (A) Blood agar: It supports growth of many bacteria but does not support certain fastidious organisms like Haemophilus influenzae, which require chocolate agar.
  • (B) Chocolate agar: This enriched medium is created by heating blood agar, causing the red blood cells to lyse. This releases nutrients that support the growth of fastidious organisms like Haemophilus influenzae, meningococci, gonococci
  • (C) Nutrient agar: This is a simple medium that supports non-fastidious bacteria but is not suited for highly demanding bacteria.
  • (D) Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA): This selective medium is used for enteric pathogens (Salmonella, Shigella) but is not designed to support fastidious organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the characteristic microscopic appearance of a pilocytic astrocytoma?
questions.solution:
A) Pseudopalisading necrosis is a feature of glioblastoma, a high-grade glioma.

B) The presence of Rosenthal fibers is a hallmark of pilocytic astrocytoma. These fibers are corkscrew-shaped, eosinophilic structures that are composed of intermediate filaments.

C) Homer-Wright rosettes are a feature of medulloblastoma, a type of primitive neuroectodermal tumor.

D) Perivascular lymphocytic infiltration

Perivascular lymphocytic infiltration can be seen in lymphoma, most commonly primary CNS lymphomas. They show a characteristic phenomenon called Hooping

Key Takeaway:

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a type of brain tumor that is typically seen in children and young adults. It is a low-grade glioma that is characterized by a distinct microscopic appearance.

The characteristic microscopic features of pilocytic astrocytoma include:

  • Biphasic pattern: The tumor has a biphasic pattern, with areas of compact, fibrillary astrocytes alternating with areas of loose, microcystic astrocytes.
  • Rosenthal fibers: The presence of Rosenthal fibers is a hallmark of pilocytic astrocytoma. These fibers are corkscrew-shaped, eosinophilic structures that are composed of intermediate filaments.
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: These are small, eosinophilic structures that are composed of degenerated astrocytic processes.
  • Low cellularity: Pilocytic astrocytomas are typically low-cellularity tumors.
  • Absence of mitotic activity: These tumors typically do not show significant mitotic activity.

Rosenthal fibers found in a pilocytic astrocytoma. These fibers are made of Heat shock proteins and Ubiquitin

choices.text: TCBS agar: Contains sucrose, which Vibrio cholerae ferments to produce large yellow colonies.
Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA): Stimulates the growth of Vibrio cholerae and produces translucent oil drop colonies.
Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone agar (GTTTA): Encourages Vibrio cholerae growth by producing yellow colonies with a black center and a turbid halo.
MacConkey agar: Supports growth of Vibrio cholerae, producing translucent and pale colonies, which may turn pink on prolonged incubation.

questions.text: Which of the following media is incorrectly matched with its description for the selective isolation of Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Correct. TCBS agar (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose) is the most commonly used selective medium for Vibrio cholerae. It contains sucrose, which the bacterium ferments, producing yellow colonies.
  • Option B: Correct. Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA) is also a selective medium for Vibrio cholerae. The colonies produced are translucent with an oil drop appearance, making it a good medium for identifying this pathogen.
  • Option C: Incorrect. Monsur’s taurocholate tellurite peptone agar (GTTTA) is not associated with yellow colonies and black centers. Vibrio cholerae typically produces translucent colonies with a grayish-black center and a turbid halo on GTTTA, making the description in this option incorrect.
  • Option D: Correct. MacConkey agar is a mildly selective medium that can support the growth of enteric pathogens, including Vibrio cholerae, which produces translucent colonies that may turn pink due to late lactose fermentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • TCBS agar and Alkaline bile salt agar are used to select for Vibrio cholerae and produce distinct colony colors.
  • The description of colony morphology on Monsur’s GTTTA medium is key to correct identification, and yellow colonies with a black center are incorrect for this medium in cholera diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman undergoes a cystoscopy for hematuria, which reveals a 1 cm flat lesion in the bladder. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a urothelial neoplasm with severe nuclear atypia, flat urothelium and a lack of papillary architecture. What is the most likely diagnosis of the bladder lesion?
questions.solution:
A) Urothelial carcinoma in situ: Urothelial carcinoma in situ is a flat, non-invasive lesion characterized by severe nuclear atypia.

B) Low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma: Low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is a papillary tumor characterized by mild to moderate nuclear atypia.

C) High-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma: High-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is a papillary tumor characterized by severe nuclear atypia.

D) Invasive urothelial carcinoma: Invasive urothelial carcinoma is a tumor that invades the detrusor muscle of the bladder.

Key Takeaways:

  • CIS is defined as high grade malignant urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia at low to intermediate power and no papillary formation.
  • Characterized by nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia and loss of cellular polarity.
  • Flat lesion, papillary, severe atypia - features of urothelial carcinoma

questions.text: Donovanosis/Granuloma inguinale is caused by?
questions.solution:
Donovanosis (also called Granuloma inguinale) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It leads to genital ulcers and is common in tropical and subtropical regions. It shows Donovan bodies and produces pseudobuboes.

Key words- Beefy red ulcer that bleeds on touch

  • T. pallidum (Option A) is the causative organism of syphilis. Produces a painless and hard chancre
  • Chlamydia (Option B)-L2, L2, L3 serotypes causes Lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Herpes simplex (Option C) causes genital herpes, characterized by painful sores.

questions.text: Which of the following dermatophyte infections is characterized by arthrospores formed on the surface of the hair shaft?
questions.solution:
A) Endothrix: In Endothrix infections, arthrospores are formed inside the hair shaft, leading to hair shaft damage and possible alopecia.

Endothrix is associated with TVS- Tonsurans, Violaceum, Schoenlenii

B) Kerion: Kerion is an inflammatory reaction, associated with T. mentigrophytes and T.verrucosum

C) Ectothrix: In Ectothrix infections, arthrospores form on the surface of the hair shaft. Agents responsible include M. audouinii, M. canis, and T. mentagrophytes.

D) Tinea unguium: This refers to infection of the nails (onychomycosis), associated with T. rubrum

Key Takeaway:

Ectothrix infections involve arthrospores on the surface of the hair shaft, leading to different patterns of hair loss compared to Endothrix.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient brought to medicine outpatient department for hypertriglyceridemia.Later he was treated with an anti-dyslipidemic drugs developed flushing, hyperglycemia and raised liver enzymes. Which of the following drug is the most likely responsible for adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Adverse drug reactions of Nicotine

  1. Nicotinic acid is a cutaneous vasodilator: marked flushing, heat and itching
    • This is associated with release of PGD2 in the skin,
    • Minimized by starting with a low dose taken with meals
    • Gradually increasing as tolerance develops
    • Use of sustained release (SR/ER) tablet also subdues flushing.
    • Aspirin taken before niacin substantially attenuates flushing by inhibiting PG synthesis.
    • Laropiprant, a prostanoid receptor inhibitor, is a specific antiflushing drug that has been combined with nicotinic acid to minimize flushing.
  2. Dyspepsia is very common; vomiting and diarrhoea
  3. Peptic ulcer may be activated.
  4. Dryness and hyperpigmentation of skin
  5. Other long-term effects are:
    • Liver dysfunction and jaundice.
    • Hyperglycaemia, precipitation of diabetes
    • Hyperuricaemia and gout,
    • Atrial arrhythmias.

Niacin is contraindicated during pregnancy and in children.

Key takeaway

  • Nicotinic acid is a cutaneous vasodilator, marked flushing, heat and itching occur after every dose along with Liver dysfunction and jaundice. Serious liver damage is the most important risk. Hyperglycaemia, precipitation of diabetes also occurs

Other options:

Option A- Atorvastatin can also induce new onset Diabetes mellitus and raise the liver enzymes, however flushing is an important clue that favours Nicotinic acid as the correct answer

Tag: Nicotinic acid

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with history of abnormal excessive blinking and grunting sounds. He has no control of these symptoms which have increased in frequency. Which of the following medications can be used for treatment of this person?
questions.solution:
The history of the patient suggests the presence of tic disorder.

Treatment of Tic Disorder:

  • Dopamine depleter: Tetrabenazine (drug of choice)
  • Dopamine receptor blockers: Haloperidol, Fluphenazine, Pimozide
  • Atypical antipsychotics: Aripiprazole, Risperidone
  • Alpha 2 agonists: Clonidine, Guanafacine
  • Clonazepam
  • Carbamazepine
  • Botulinum toxin (Local injection)

TICS

  • A tic is a brief, rapid, recurrent, stereotyped, and seemingly purposeless motor contraction.
  • Motor tics can be simple, with movement only affecting an individual muscle group (e.g., blinking, twitching of the nose, jerking of the neck), or complex, with coordinated involvement of multiple muscle groups (e.g., jumping, sniffing, head banging, and echopraxia [mimicking movements]).
  • Phonic (or vocal) tics can also be simple (e.g., grunting) or complex (e.g., echolalia [repeating other people’s words], palilalia [repeating one’s own words], and coprolalia [expression of obscene words]).
  • Patients may also experience sensory tics, composed of unpleasant focal sensations in the face, head, or neck.
  • Patients with mild disease often only require education and counseling (for themselves and family members).
  • In a high proportion of patients, the severity of tics wanes in adult life, becoming less of a medical problem, thus arguing for conservative management if possible during the first decades of life.
  • Drug treatment is indicated when the tics are disabling and interfere with quality of life and social interactions.

Other options

  1. Carbamazepine is a sodium channel blocker
  2. Methylphenidate is a Norepinephrine Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor (for ADHD)
  3. Imipramine is a Tricyclic Antidepressant

Key takeaway:

Tic is a brief, rapid, recurrent, stereotyped, and seemingly purposeless motor contraction. Patients with mild disease often only require education and counselin. Drug treatment is indicated when the tics are disabling and interfere with quality of life and social interactions.

Tag: Tetrabenazine

questions.text: A lady got stung by a bee after which she developed shock. What is the substance that is most importantly related to the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
The substance most importantly related to the patient's presentation after a bee sting is:

Option: A) Histamine

  • Bee stings can trigger an allergic reaction, and the release of histamine is a crucial mediator in allergic reactions.
  • Histamine is released from mast cells and basophils in response to allergens, such as bee venom.
  • Histamine is a key player in the early phase of an allergic reaction, leading to symptoms like vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, bronchoconstriction, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • These effects can collectively result in anaphylaxis, a severe and potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that includes symptoms of shock.

Role of other options: While the other options contribute to the inflammatory response, their significance in bee sting shock is less prominent:

  • Leukotrienes:These are also released by mast cells and contribute to bronchoconstriction and inflammation, but their impact on bee sting shock is secondary to histamine's vasodilatory effects.
  • Bradykinin:This molecule triggers vasodilation and pain, but its involvement in bee sting shock is less pronounced compared to histamine's widespread effects.
  • Complement:The complement system is part of the immune response, but its primary role is in opsonization and clearance of pathogens, not directly related to the immediate vasodilatory and hypotensive effects seen in bee sting shock.

Type I Hypersensitivity Reactions: Anaphylaxis

Anaphylaxis:

  1. Definition:
    • Two forms: acute, potentially fatal systemic anaphylaxis and chronic or recurrent, non-fatal, localized atopy.
    • Anaphylaxis is the classical immediate hypersensitivity reaction.
  2. Features:
    • Antigens and haptens can induce anaphylaxis.
    • Sensitization requires an interval of at least 2-3 weeks between doses.
    • Shocking dose is most effective when injected intravenously.
    • Shocking antigen must be identical or immunologically closely related to the sensitizing antigen.
  3. Clinical Features of Anaphylaxis:
    • Smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, bronchoconstriction.
    • Target tissues or shock organs affected vary between species.
    • Clinical effects: edema, decreased coagulability of blood, fall in blood pressure, temperature, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
  4. Human Anaphylaxis:
    • Itching, flushing, difficulty in breathing, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, hypotension, loss of consciousness, and death.
    • Commonly associated with antibiotic or drug injections, insect stings.
    • Epinephrine injection is life-saving.
  5. Types of Anaphylaxis:
    • Cutaneous anaphylaxis: Local wheal-and-flare response.
    • Passive cutaneous anaphylaxis (PCA): In vivo method for detecting antibodies.
    • Anaphylaxis in vitro: Isolated tissues contract in response to the specific antigen.
  6. Mechanism:
    • IgE antibody plays a central role.
    • IgE is bound to mast cells and basophils, leading to degranulation upon exposure to the shocking dose.
    • Pharmacological mediators: Histamine, serotonin, chemotactic factors, enzymatic mediators, prostaglandins, leukotrienes, platelet activating factor (PAF).
  7. Anaphylactoid Reaction:
    • Non-specific mechanism involving complement activation and release of anaphylatoxins.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of ADHD?
questions.solution:
• Catecholamine Reuptake Inhibitors
    • Many inhibitors of the amine transporters for norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin are used clinically.
  • Atomoxetine is a selective inhibitor of the norepinephrine reuptake transporter.
    • Its actions, therefore, are mediated by potentiation of norepinephrine levels in noradrenergic synapses.
    • It is used in the treatment of attention deficit disorders
  • Reboxetine has similar characteristics to atomoxetine but is used mainly for major depression disorder.
    • Because reuptake inhibitors potentiate norepinephrine actions, there is concern about their cardiovascular safety.
    • Atomoxetine has surprisingly little cardiovascular effect because it has a clonidine-like effect in the CNS to decrease sympathetic outflow
  • Sibutramine, a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used as an appetite suppressant, was taken off the market because it was associated with a small increase in cardiovascular events, including strokes, in patients with a history of cardiovascular disease.
  • Duloxetine is a widely used antidepressant with balanced serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitory effects.

Key takeaway: Reboxetine has similar characteristics to atomoxetine but is used mainly for major depression disorder & treatment of attention deficit disorders

Tag: Reboxetine

questions.text: Identify the given image
questions.solution:
Marbling refers to a characteristic post-mortem change observed in decomposing bodies. It results from the breakdown of hemoglobin in the blood and the subsequent infiltration of decomposed blood into the subcutaneous veins. The veins become prominent, forming a web-like pattern of greenish-black or purplish discoloration, resembling a marbled appearance.

Mechanism: Decomposition bacteria produce gases, increasing intravascular pressure, which forces hemolyzed blood into the superficial veins.

Appearance: The pattern of marbling typically follows the venous structures, especially in areas with thin skin like the thighs, abdomen, and arms.

In the given scenario, the image likely depicts this characteristic marbling pattern, identifying it as a post-mortem change due to decomposition.

Rule Out

Post-mortem lividity (a):

Post-mortem lividity (or hypostasis) refers to the settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body due to gravity after death. It appears as a uniform purplish-red discoloration and does not follow venous patterns like marbling.

Filigree burns (c):

Filigree burns occur due to high-voltage electrical injuries where the current creates an arborescent (tree-branch-like) pattern on the skin. Unlike marbling, filigree burns are linear, raised, and do not involve discoloration due to decomposition.

None (d):

The described image clearly matches the features of marbling and thus cannot be categorized as "none."

Key Takeaways

Marbling is a prominent decomposition change seen in the early stages of putrefaction and follows the superficial venous patterns.

It should not be confused with other post-mortem changes like lividity or external injuries like burns.

Proper identification of marbling aids in determining the post-mortem interval (PMI) and understanding the progression of decomposition in forensic cases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with symptoms of bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal impairment. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a treatment regimen. Which of the following treatments is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster?
questions.solution:
Bortezomib

  • It is a unique boron containing compound that covalently binds to proteasome and inhibits its proteolytic activity, disrupting many intracellular signalling pathways.
  • The most important of these is nuclear factor-κB (NF-κB) mediated signalling.
  • NF-κB is a transcription factor that normally resides in the cytoplasm bound to an inhibitory protein Iκ
  • Some neoplasms overexpress NFκΒ which plays an important role in their survival.
  • By inhibiting proteasome, bortezomib prevents the breakup and degradation of IκB, so that NFκB is not released to transcript survival molecules.
  • The prime indication of bortezomib is multiple myeloma which over expresses NFkb, both for first line combined therapy (along with cytotoxic drugs), as well as for relapsed disease.
  • It is also used for refractory mantle cell lymphoma.
  • The most prominent adverse effect is peripheral neuropathy
  • Others are diarrhoea, fatigue, bone marrow depression, especially thrombocytopenia.

Key takeaway: The prime indication of bortezomib is multiple myeloma which over expresses NFkb, both for first line combined therapy (along with cytotoxic drugs), as well as for relapsed disease

Tag: Bortezomib

questions.text: Match the following poisons and antidotes:
questions.solution:
The question involves matching poisons to their specific antidotes, which are substances used to neutralize or counteract the effects of the poison. The correct matches are as follows:

Paracetamol (b. N-acetylcysteine):

Paracetamol overdose leads to hepatotoxicity due to the accumulation of a toxic metabolite (NAPQI). N-acetylcysteine acts as a precursor for glutathione synthesis, which detoxifies NAPQI, preventing liver damage.

Nicotine (d. Bupropion):

Nicotine poisoning, often from tobacco products, affects the central nervous system. Bupropion, an atypical antidepressant, is used to manage nicotine addiction and counter the overstimulation caused by nicotine.

Morphine (e. Nalorphine):

Morphine, a potent opioid, can cause respiratory depression in overdose situations. Nalorphine, an opioid antagonist, competes with morphine at opioid receptors to reverse its toxic effects.

Hydrogen Cyanide (HCN) (a. Amyl nitrite):

HCN poisoning disrupts cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase. Amyl nitrite works as a cyanide antidote by inducing methemoglobin formation, which binds cyanide ions, reducing its toxicity.

Rule Out:

a) Incorrect because it pairs Paracetamol with Nalorphine (e), which is used for opioids, not for paracetamol toxicity. Nicotine is also incorrectly paired with Nalorphine.

c) Incorrect because Paracetamol is paired with Bupropion (d), which is used for nicotine, not paracetamol toxicity. Morphine is incorrectly paired with Trimethadione (f), which is an anticonvulsant, not an opioid antidote.

d) Incorrect because all pairings are wrong. Paracetamol is paired with Amyl Nitrite (a), which is used for cyanide poisoning, and other antidotes are misassigned as well.

Key Takeaways:

Correct Pairings of Antidotes:

  • Paracetamol: N-acetylcysteine
  • Nicotine: Bupropion
  • Morphine: Nalorphine
  • HCN: Amyl nitrite

Mechanism of Antidotes:

  • N-acetylcysteine replenishes glutathione stores to neutralize toxic metabolites.
  • Bupropion helps reduce nicotine cravings and counteracts overstimulation.
  • Nalorphine acts as an opioid receptor antagonist to reverse opioid toxicity.
  • Amyl nitrite facilitates cyanide detoxification by inducing methemoglobin formation.

Understanding Toxicity Management:

  • Antidotes work by targeting the specific physiological or biochemical pathways affected by poisons. Recognizing these pairings is crucial in emergency toxicology and forensic medicine.

choices.text: Erythromycin induced inhibition of clotting factors synthesis
Erythromycin induced inhibition of warfarin metabolism
Warfarin induced thrombosis of the nasal mucosal microvasculature
Warfarin-induced decreased of vitamin K production by intestinal flora

questions.text: A 62 year old woman complained to her physician of nose bleeds and red eyes. The woman had been receiving warfarin for 1 month because of deep venous thrombosis. Four days earlier, she had started treatment with erythromycin for acute pharyngitis. Which of the following drug-induced changes was most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Macrolide antibiotics can inhibit warfarin metabolism, resulting in increased plasma levels of the drug.
  • This interaction is well established, and prolongation of prothrombin time may occur even with small doses of erythromycin.
  • Warfarin shows a number of drug interactions, therefore requires dose adjustment with several medications.

Drugs increasing the effect of warfarin, thus requiring dose reduction Includes.

  • Broad spectrum antibiotics, cephalosporins like cefamandole, cefoperazone and moxalactam (cause hypoprothrombinemia)
  • Aspirin, phenylbutazone
  • Various microsomal enzyme inhibitors (isoniazid, amiodarone, erythromycin, cimetidine ).

Drugs decrease the effect and thus require increase in dose of warfarin.

  • Enzyme inducers (like rifampicin, carbamazepine, griseofulvin, )
  • Oral contraceptives (increase clotting factors)

Option A: Erythromycin does not inhibit the synthesis of clotting factors.

Option C: Warfarin can cause local thrombosis that seems related to the inhibition of anticoagulant protein C, but this adverse effect is rare and usually occurs during the first day of warfarin therapy when the anticoagulant effect is not yet operative.

Option D: Warfarin does not affect production of vitamin K by intestinal flora

Key takeaway:

  • Macrolide antibiotics can inhibit warfarin metabolism, resulting in increased plasma levels of the drug.
  • This interaction is well established, and prolongation of prothrombin time may occur even with small doses of erythromycin.

Tag: Warfarin

questions.text: A 29 year old woman at 8 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for treatment of her hyperthyroid status?
questions.solution:
• Since propylthiouracil has shorter duration of action and carries risk of
  • severe hepatitis, it should be reserved for use in early pregnancy (due to less placental transfer than carbimazole) and in thyroid storm for its inhibitory action on peripheral conversion of T4 to more active T3.
  • It may be tried in patients developing adverse effects with carbimazole
  • Methimazole and propylthiouracil are thioamides used as antithyroid agents.
  • These drugs inhibit thyroid peroxidase, the enzyme that catalyzes the following three steps in thyroid hormone biosynthesis:
    • Oxidation of iodide to iodine
    • Iodination of tyrosine residues within thyroglobulin
    • Combination of two diiodotyrosines (DITs), leading to T4, and combination of monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and DIT, which leads to T3.

By blocking the enzyme, the synthesis of thyroid hormones is blocked.

  • Thioamides bind to the thyroid peroxidise and prevent oxidation of iodide and iodotyrosyl residues, thereby;
  • Inhibit iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin
  • Inhibit coupling of iodotyrosine residues to form T3 and T4.
    • In addition, propylthiouracil and, to a lesser extent, methimazole inhibit the peripheral deiodination of T4 and T3.

Key takeaway

Propylthiouracil has shorter duration of action and carries risk of

  • severe hepatitis, it should be reserved for use in early pregnancy (due to less placental transfer than carbimazole)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an effect of ROS?
questions.solution:
A) Lipid peroxidation: ROS can cause lipid peroxidation, leading to the formation of lipid radicals and lipid peroxides.

B) Protein oxidation: ROS can cause protein oxidation, leading to the formation of protein carbonyls and protein nitrotyrosine.

C) DNA damage: ROS can cause DNA damage, including strand breaks, base modifications, and epigenetic changes.

D) Increased cellular energy production: ROS do not typically increase cellular energy production. In fact, ROS can damage mitochondrial DNA, proteins, and lipids, leading to decreased cellular energy production.

Key takeaways:

  1. ROS can cause lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, and DNA damage leading to cellular injury and disease.
  2. ROS can damage mitochondrial DNA, proteins, and lipids, leading to decreased cellular energy production.
  3. Antioxidant defenses, such as vitamin E and CoQ10, can help to protect cells against ROS damage.

choices.text: Molecular mimicry between liver antigens and viral proteins
Loss of tolerance to liver-specific antigens
Abnormal expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with jaundice, fatigue, and loss of appetite. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of liver enzymes and autoantibodies. A liver biopsy is performed, and histological examination reveals interface hepatitis, piecemeal necrosis, and lobular inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism underlying the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) Molecular mimicry between liver antigens and viral proteins: Molecular mimicry is a mechanism in which the immune system mistakenly recognizes liver antigens as viral proteins, leading to an autoimmune response.

B) Loss of tolerance to liver-specific antigens: Loss of tolerance to liver-specific antigens is a mechanism in which the immune system fails to recognize liver antigens as self, leading to an autoimmune response.

C) Abnormal expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules: Abnormal expression of MHC class II molecules is a mechanism in which the immune system presents liver antigens to T cells in an abnormal manner, leading to an autoimmune response.

D) All of the above: The pathogenesis of autoimmune hepatitis is complex and multifactorial, involving a combination of molecular mimicry, loss of tolerance to liver-specific antigens, and abnormal expression of MHC class II molecules.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Autoimmune hepatitis is a complex and multifactorial disease: The pathogenesis of autoimmune hepatitis involves a combination of genetic, environmental, and immune system factors.
  2. Molecular mimicry, loss of tolerance, and abnormal expression of MHC class II molecules are all mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of autoimmune hepatitis: Understanding the mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of autoimmune hepatitis is essential for the development of effective treatments.
    1. Liver biopsy is essential for diagnosing autoimmune hepatitis, as it allows for histological examination of the liver tissue.
    2. Autoimmune hepatitis will show Rosettes, emperipolesis

choices.text: Activation of adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activated protein kinase
Activation of glucagon like polypeptide-2 (GLP-2) receptors

questions.text: A 50 year old obese woman with type 2 diabetes was adequately control of her disease 2 months after starting therapy with metformin and glyburide. Later she diagnosed of having short bowel syndrome.Her physician decided to add teduglutide to the treatment regimen. Which of the following molecular actions most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of the added drug in the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Short-Bowel Syndrome

  • Short-bowel syndrome is a malabsorption disorder caused by removal of the small intestine or rarely because of a congenital bowel abnormality.
  • Short-bowel syndrome requires total parenteral nutrition, and treatments are aimed at reducing the need for this, including supplemented special­ized diets and implementing a therapy based on physiologic principles of the actions of gut hormones.

TEDUGLUTIDE:

  • It is a recombinant analog of human glucagon like peptide 2.
  • It is used for the treatment of adults with short bowel syndrome.
  • It works by promoting mucosal growth and possibly restoring gastric
  • emptying and secretion.
  • It is given by subcutaneous route.
  • It is long acting drug because it is resistant to degradation by DPP-4

Therapeutic Uses and Adverse Effects

  • Teduglutide is administered subcutaneously once daily (0.05 mg/kg) to help improve intestinal absorption of nutrients and thereby reduce the need for parenteral sup­port.
  • Common side effects include abdominal pain, nausea, headache, and flu-like symptoms.
  • There is also the potential for teduglutide to cause cancer of the bowel; therefore, it is not recommended for patients with active malignancies.

Other options

  • Inhibition of dipeptidyl peptidase-4 - Gliptins
  • Inhibition of α -glucosidase- Voglibose and Acarbose
  • Activation of adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activated protein kinase- Metformin

Key takeaway

  • It is a recombinant analog of human glucagon like peptide 2. It is used for the treatment of adults with short bowel syndrome.
  • Other of adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activated protein kinase- Metformin

questions.text:
Match the following columns

1. Adipocere
2. Livor Mortis
3. Mummification
4. Marbling
questions.solution:
The question requires matching postmortem changes or decomposition phenomena with their corresponding features. Here is the detailed Explanation for each term:

Adipocere (D-1):

Definition: Adipocere, or "grave wax," is a waxy substance formed by the hydrolysis of body fats in a moist, anaerobic environment. It is characterized by a grayish-white, cheesy consistency.

Formation: It occurs weeks to months after death, especially in bodies submerged in water or buried in damp conditions.

Key feature: Preservation of body tissues due to saponification of fats.

Livor Mortis (B-3):

Definition: Also called postmortem lividity, it is the purplish-red discoloration of the skin due to gravitational pooling of blood in dependent areas after death.

Onset: Begins within 20-30 minutes after death and becomes fixed after 6-12 hours.

Key feature: Indicates the position of the body after death and can help determine if the body was moved.

Mummification (C-2):

Definition: Mummification is the desiccation or drying of tissues due to loss of moisture, typically in hot and dry environments.

Formation: It occurs over weeks to months and results in a leathery appearance of the body.

Key feature: Preservation of the body due to dehydration, inhibiting bacterial growth.

Marbling (A-4):

Definition: Marbling refers to the appearance of a web-like pattern on the skin caused by the decomposition of blood vessels, leading to the spread of hydrogen sulfide gas along veins.

Onset: Seen within 24-48 hours after death.

Key feature: Greenish-black discoloration following the venous pattern.

Rule Out:

Option (a): A-1 B-2 C-3 D-4:

Why ruled out: This incorrectly matches marbling (A) with adipocere (1), which is inconsistent with the venous discoloration characteristic of marbling.

Option (b): A-4 B-1 C-2 D-3:

Why ruled out: This incorrectly matches livor mortis (B) with adipocere (1). Livor mortis is associated with postmortem discoloration due to blood pooling, not fat saponification.

Option (c): A-4 B-2 C-1 D-3:

Why ruled out: This mismatches mummification (C) with adipocere (1). Mummification is related to desiccation, not fat transformation.

Key Takeaways:

Adipocere: Formed by fat saponification in moist, anaerobic environments; leads to tissue preservation.

Livor Mortis: Postmortem blood pooling; indicates body position and timing of death.

Mummification: Tissue dehydration in dry environments; results in a leathery appearance.

Marbling: Venous discoloration due to hydrogen sulfide gas spreading along veins; occurs early in decomposition.

Forensic relevance: Each phenomenon provides critical clues about postmortem interval (PMI), environmental conditions, and cause of death.

questions.text: An adult patient is a known case of bronchial asthma. He has a history of regular medication. The nasal examination shows the presence of nasal polypi. Which drug he is most likely sensitive to?
questions.solution:
Samter's Triad consists of:

  1. Bronchial Asthma
  2. Nasal Polyposis
  3. Aspirin (NSAID) sensitivity

Patients with this triad often develop respiratory symptoms (e.g., bronchospasm, rhinorrhea, nasal congestion) after taking aspirin or other NSAIDs.

This is not a classic IgE-mediated allergy, but a pseudo allergic reaction due to inhibition of the cyclooxygenase (COX)-1 enzyme, leading to:

  • Decreased prostaglandin E2 (which normally has anti-inflammatory properties)
  • Increased leukotriene production → bronchospasm, inflammation, and mucosal edema

"Metastatic lymph node from a nasopharyngeal carcinoma" explains all the findings:

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause hernia?
questions.solution:
• Muscle damage by blunt trauma or tearing of the abdominal muscles requires exceptional force and is rare.
  • Causes of hernia

Weakness due to structures entering and leaving the abdomen

  • Developmental failures
  • Genetic weakness of collagen
  • Sharp and blunt trauma
  • Weakness due to ageing and pregnancy

  • Despite the complex design of the abdominal wall, the only natural weaknesses caused
  • by inadequate muscular strength are the lumbar triangles and the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • An inguinal hernia (indirect) also occurs through the developmental failure of the processus vaginalis to close
  • Excessive intra-abdominal pressure
  • Despite the complex design of the abdominal wall, the only natural weaknesses caused
  • by inadequate muscular strength are the lumbar triangles and the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • An inguinal hernia (indirect) also occurs through the developmental failure of the processus vaginalis to close
  • Muscle damage by blunt trauma or tearing of the abdominal muscles requires exceptional force and is rare.

questions.text: Identify the management method given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
• There are various management methods and techniques, the one given in the image is network analysis.
  • A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.
  • The two common types of network technique are a) PERT and b) CPM.
  • PERT (programme evaluation and review technique) is a management technique which makes possible more detailed planning and more comprehensive supervision.
  • The essence of PERT is to construct an arrow diagram. The diagram represents the logical sequence in which events must take place. It is possible with such a diagram to calculate the time by which each activity must be completed, and to identify those activities that are critical.
  • CPM (critical path method): - The longest path of the network is called critical path. If any activity along the critical path is delayed, the entire project will be delayed.
  • Two common types
    1. Programme evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)
    2. Critical Path method (CPM)

questions.text: Which one of the following is most common benign tumor of lung?
questions.solution:
BENIGN LUNG TUMOURS

  • Benign tumours of the lung are uncommon and account for fewer than 15% of solitary lesions seen on chest radiographs.
  • A peripheral tumour usually causes no symptoms until it is large; a central tumour may present with haemoptysis and signs of bronchial obstruction while still small.
  • A tumour is likely to be benign if it has not increased in size on chest radiographs for more than 2 years or it has some degree of calcification; however, a tissue diagnosis is usually pursued.
  • Most benign nodules are granulomas (tuberculosis or histoplasmosis).
  • The most common benign tumour is a hamartoma, a developmental abnormality containing mesothelial and endothelial elements.
  • Diagnosis (and definitive treatment) is achieved by excision of the lesion. Any of the mesodermal elements of the lung may form a mesodermal tumour (chondroma, lipoma, leiomyoma).
  • Deposits of amyloid may have a similar radiographic appearance to a nodule (pseudotumour).

questions.text: A chest physician observed that the distribution of forced expiratory volume FEV in 300 smokers had a median value of 2.5 litres with the first and third quartile being 1.5 and 4.5 litres respectively. Based on this data how many persons in the sample are expected to have a FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres?
questions.solution:
• Median value of 2.5 litres (Q2) with the first(Q1) and third(Q3) quartile being 1.5 and 4.5 litres respectively.
  • Quartile divides the distribution into four equal parts having 25% of distribution each.
  • Hence between Q1 and Q3 there are fifty percent observations.
  • Thus 50% of the smokers have FEV value between 1.5 and 4.5 litres.
  • Fifty percent of 300 will come out to be 150.

choices.text: Split-thickness skin graft can be expand from ratio of 1:1.5 to 1:6
Most used donor site is thigh
Vascularisation is not needed for graft take on a bed
