questions.text: All are the following statements are correct regarding split thickness skin graft except?
questions.solution:
• Split-thickness skin grafts Split-thickness skin grafts are taken with either hand-held or powered skin knives. The most used donor site is the thigh, with the buttock preferable in children and cosmetically sensitive individuals. For larger grafts, almost any flat surface can be harvested, including the scalp if shaved (a very good and useful donor site).
  • The thickness of the graft harvested, ease of graft 'take' and donor site healing must be weighed against the lack of durability of thin split-thickness skin grafts.
  • Split grafts can be perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve 'take'; they can be further meshed to allow expansion.
  • This is carried out on a device that cuts a series of slits along the skin, allowing it to expand from a ratio of anything from 1:1.5 to about 1:6.
  • Grafts will only take on a bed on which they can become vascularized. Preparation of the wound bed is therefore an essential part of a successful graft.
  • Graft failure is commonly caused by pus, exudate or residual dead tissue beneath the skin, haematoma or shearing forces. A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage success.
  • Split-thickness skin grafts consist of epidermis and a variable amount of dermis and are sometimes referred to as Thiersch grafts. They are commonly harvested from the thigh using a dermatome or graft knife to achieve a consistent depth. It is relatively simple to harvest large areas of skin to reconstruct sizeable defects such as those following a significant burn injury

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient came to emergency department with severe pain in the chest and abdomen with history of shortness of breath since 1 day. There is upper abdominal rigidity. Patient had history of vomiting after heavy alcohol intake before the onset of symptoms. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young male patient vomiting after drinking causes spontaneous perforation of the lower

oesophagus which causes severe pain in the chest and upper abdomen

It is also associated with shortness of breath due to mediastinitis.

So most probable diagnosis is boerhaave's syndrome

Barotrauma (spontaneous perforation, Boerhaave's syndrome)

  • This occurs classically when a person vomits against a closed glottis. The pressure in the oesophagus increases rapidly, and the oesophagus bursts at its weakest point in the lower third, sending a stream of material into the mediastinum and often the pleural cavity as well.
  • Patients with Boerhaave's syndrome may have the classic triad of vomiting, chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema.
  • There may or may not be associated haematemesis
  • Typically, the site of perforation is the lower oesophagus towards the left pleural cavity.
  • Gastric juice as well as ingested food is forcefully ejected into the left chest. A left pleural effusion rapidly accumulates.

Physical examination reveals subcutaneous emphysema on the chest wall, sometimes extending to the cervical region as well.

Patients with cervical oesophageal or pharyngeal perforation are usually much less septic than those with intrathoracic perforations and mediastinitis.

A typical example would be foreign body perforation, such as by a sharp fishbone, having lodged at the postcricoid area and perforated the oesophagus.

There may be a history of foreign body ingestion and neck pain and physical examination may reveal tenderness and subcutaneous emphysema.

  • Option a) Perforated peptic perforation: There will not be severe chest pain in the initial period of perforated peptic ulcer patient
  • Option b) Myocardial infarction: There would be pain in the chest radiating to the left arm. But vomiting might occur after the pain. But here vomiting is followed by chest and abdominal pain. And there won't be abdominal rigidity in myocardial infarction.
  • Option d) Pancreatitis: There will not be severe chest pain and shortness of breath in the initial period or presenting complain of the patient of acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which among the following genes is NOT associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)?
questions.solution:
(A) NOD2:

Strongly associated with Crohn's disease (a form of IBD).

NOD2 gene encodes a receptor involved in the immune response to bacterial products.

Mutations in NOD2 increase susceptibility to Crohn's disease.

(B) MHC:

Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) genes, particularly HLA class II alleles (e.g., HLA-DRB1), are associated with both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

These genes regulate immune responses and are crucial in autoimmune conditions.

(C) CARD15:

CARD15 is an older name for NOD2.

Like NOD2, CARD15 mutations are associated with an increased risk for Crohn's disease.

choices.text: Use of GnRH antagonists in ovulation induction

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for developing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)?
questions.solution:
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is one of the most significant risk factors for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS). Women with PCOS typically have an increased number of ovarian follicles, which makes them more sensitive to stimulation during ovulation induction, especially in assisted reproductive technologies (ART) like in vitro fertilization (IVF). This heightened sensitivity can lead to excessive ovarian response and the development of OHSS, a condition where the ovaries become swollen and painful due to fluid accumulation.

Here's why the other options are not significant risk factors:

  • A) Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is associated with lower ovarian reserve and fewer oocytes, it is not directly linked to an increased risk of OHSS compared to conditions like PCOS.
  • B) Low AMH (Anti-Müllerian Hormone): Low AMH levels typically indicate a reduced ovarian reserve and a lower number of follicles, which would actually reduce the risk of OHSS, rather than increase it.
  • D) Use of GnRH antagonists in ovulation induction: GnRH antagonists are often used in ART to prevent premature ovulation, thus reducing the risk of OHSS, not increasing it. In contrast, the use of GnRH agonists or high doses of gonadotropins is more commonly associated with an increased risk.

Reference: American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM). "Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)."

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman in her first pregnancy has a forceps-assisted delivery due to failure to progress in the second stage of labor. Post-delivery, she experiences a marked decrease in sensation over the inner thigh and difficulty lifting her leg.
Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
• Obturator nerve injury is a known complication of forceps deliveries due to the force exerted on the pelvis and lower limbs during the procedure. This nerve provides sensation to the inner thigh and motor function to the adductor muscles, leading to weakness in leg movements.
  • Sciatic nerve (A) injury can occur but typically results in foot drop or difficulty moving the foot, not inner thigh sensory changes.
  • Femoral nerve (B) injury can lead to weakness in the quadriceps, but the sensory loss described is more typical of obturator nerve damage.
  • Pudendal nerve (D) injury affects perineal sensation and is more commonly associated with difficult deliveries but not the thigh.

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin: "Operative Vaginal Delivery" (ACOG, 2016)

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vague abdominal symptoms and a palpable pelvic mass. Her CA-125 level is markedly elevated. The next step in management should be:
questions.solution:
1. Laparoscopy for biopsy
    • While laparoscopy can be useful for diagnosing ovarian tumors, it is not the first-line investigation when there is a strong suspicion of ovarian cancer, particularly in a postmenopausal woman with elevated CA-125 levels. Surgical staging and biopsy are typically done after imaging has been performed.
  2. CT scan for staging
    • Correct Answer. The next step in management for a patient with an elevated CA-125 level and a palpable pelvic mass is imaging to determine the extent of the disease and evaluate for metastasis. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the most appropriate for staging ovarian cancer, as it helps assess the size, location, and extent of the tumor, as well as any possible metastasis to lymph nodes or other organs. This helps guide treatment and surgical planning.
  3. Immediate initiation of chemotherapy
    • Chemotherapy is initiated after confirming the diagnosis and staging of ovarian cancer. It is not appropriate to start chemotherapy without confirming the diagnosis and extent of the disease through imaging and possibly biopsy.
  4. MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
    • An MRI can also be useful for evaluating ovarian tumors, particularly in certain cases where detailed soft tissue resolution is needed. However, a CT scan is more commonly used as the initial imaging modality for staging ovarian cancer due to its availability and ability to detect both the tumor and any metastasis to lymph nodes, liver, or other organs.

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG). (2015). Practice Bulletin No. 174: Management of Ovarian Cancer.

choices.text: Lattice degeneration with associated retinal thinning
Aphakia or pseudophakia following cataract surgery
Chronic uveitis with subretinal fluid accumulation
Acute posterior vitreous detachment with vitreoretinal traction

questions.text: Which of the following is the LEAST likely to be a contributing factor to the development of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD)

  • Incidence:
    • RRD affects approximately 1 in 10,000 people annually.
    • Both eyes are eventually affected in about 10% of cases.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • RRD is characterized by:
      • Presence of a retinal break combined with vitreoretinal traction.
      • Accumulation of liquefied vitreous under the neurosensory retina, separating it from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
    • Retinal detachment is unlikely without partial vitreous liquefaction or traction.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Myopia:
      • Over 40% of RRDs occur in myopic eyes.
      • The risk increases with higher refractive errors.
      • Myopic eyes are prone to:
        • Vitreous degeneration and posterior vitreous detachment (PVD).
        • Predisposing lesions like lattice degeneration and snailtrack degeneration.
        • Small round holes in chorioretinal atrophy and macular holes.
  • Surgical and Procedural Risks:
    • Vitreous loss during cataract surgery.
    • Laser capsulotomy (especially in highly myopic eyes).

questions.text:
The endocrinopathies that increase the risk of Diabetes mellitus:
1. Cushing syndrome
2. Acromegaly
3. Hyperthyroidism
4. Pheochromocytoma
questions.solution:

  • Hyperthyroidism cause hyperglycemia by increasing the clearance of insulin and producing abnormalities in processing of insulin.

questions.text: A 5-year-old was admitted to PICU for altered mental status and suspected meningitis. The child presents with generalized tonic clonic seizures since last 1 hour. You promptly administer benzodiazepines, fluids, and ceftriaxone and vancomycin. Despite anticonvulsants, the seizure persists. Which complication of meningitis is most likely to cause a seizure that is refractory to the above treatments?
questions.solution:
• Hyponatremia from the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of ADH (SIADH) is a common complication of bacterial meningitis.
  • Hyponatremic seizures are notoriously resistant to anticonvulsants and need to be treated with appropriate saline solutions.
  • A brain abscess (choice A) is a complication that may cause seizures, but usually is not one of the presenting signs. This complication may need neurosurgical care.
  • Again, subdural empyema (choice B) is not a presenting sign, but seizures resulting from irritation from an empyema usually respond well to therapy.
  • Increased ICP (choice D) is a possible complication from meningitis and may cause seizures (but not as common as hyponatremia).

choices.text: Flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius
Flow is inversely proportional to the pressure difference
Resistance is directly proportional to the length

questions.text: When a smaller intravenous cannula is replaced by a wider bore; when the intravenous fluid is kept at a higher level, both allows faster emptying of the fluid. This is because of the following statements:
questions.solution:
• Poiseuille's Law:
    • Q = (π * ΔP * r⁴) / (8 * η * L)
  • Where:
    • Q = Flow rate
    • ΔP = Pressure difference between two ends
    • r = Radius of the tube (cannula)
    • η = Viscosity of the fluid
    • L = Length of the tube
  • Option A: According to the Hagen-Poiseuille law, which describes laminar flow in tubes, the flow resistance, R, is dependent on the length of the tube and the viscosity of the fluid, but inversely related to the fourth power of the radius
  • Hence, Flow(F) is directly proportional to fourth power of radius
  • Option B: more the amount of pressure higher the flow, hence it is directly proportional not inversely proportional
  • Option C: Longer the length of the tube higher the surface tension and higher the resistance, hence it is directly proportional
  • Hence, option D: both A&C are correct

questions.text: A 36 year old patient presented with flaccid bullae and crusted erosions predominantly over face, scalp, upper chest and upperback. The histopathology is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In Pemphigus vulgaris

  • oral mucous membranes are usually affected with or without skin involvement,
  • Flaccid blisters-which may occur anywhere on the skin surface-are the primary lesion of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Histologically there is suprabasal cleft with acantholytic cells.

Pemphigus foliaceous

  • only the skin is affected.
  • the blister is even more fragile than in PV, and therefore skin lesions usually present as scaly-crusted small erosions,
  • Histologically, there is subcorneal cleft.

The Nikolsky sign is positive in PF patients with active disease.

Bullous pemphigoid

  • mainly affects elderly people
  • starts with pruritus and urticated and erythematous lesions.
  • Later, tense blisters are characteristic both on erythematous and on normal skin.
  • Mucosal :in a minority of patients and is not predominant.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal splitting.

Key takeaway:

Pemphigus foliaceous

  • Flaccid bulla- Think of Pemphigus
  • Subcorneal split in histopath
  • only the skin is affected.
  • the blister is even more fragile than in PV, and therefore skin lesions usually present as scaly-crusted small erosions,
  • Histologically, there is subcorneal cleft.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department after a nervous breakdown. He says that he got divorced about a week ago and has been feeling depressed since then. He has also started hearing voices for the past few days, saying he is useless and telling him to kill himself. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. Schizophrenia

Duration ≥ 6 months (with ≥1 month of active symptoms), Must have at least 2 of: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized/catatonic behavior, negative symptoms, Not likely here: duration is only a few days

B. Schizophreniform Disorder

Similar to schizophrenia but duration is 1 to 6 months, Not likely here: symptoms only present for a few days

C. Brief Psychotic Disorder (Correct Answer)

Duration: 1 day to 1 month, with eventual full return to baseline functioning, At least one psychotic symptom: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech/behavior Can be with marked stressor (a specifier in DSM-5)

Fits perfectly: recent divorce (stressor), hallucinations for few days, total duration <1 month

D. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD)

Requires ≥2 weeks of depressive symptoms, Psychotic features can occur, but then it’s termed "MDD with psychotic features" In MDD with psychotic features, hallucinations are usually mood-congruent and persistent. However, in this case, psychotic symptoms are too acute and isolated to call it MDD

Conclusion:

This man has an acute onset of psychotic symptoms (hallucinations), triggered by a stressor (divorce), lasting only a few days - classic presentation of Brief Psychotic Disorder (with marked stressor)

questions.text:
A 63 year old man complains of a 6 month history of lethargy, fever, weight loss, arthralgia and diarrhoea. Jejunal biopsy reveals flattened mucosa with evidence of periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS positive inclusions in the macrophages in a patient with chronic malnutrition, with arthralgia and fever may be either Tuberculosis or Whipple's Disease. Both of them cause PAS positive macrophages. But Mycobacterium tuberculosis is acid-fast, where as Trophyrema whipplei is non acid fast.

Since the question does not mention anything about the acid fastness, we assume it to be negative. Moreover, Tuberculosis mainly affects the ileum, here jejunum is involved.

This is a case of Whipple's disease.

  • It is a chronic, multiorgan disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei - gram-positive, non-acid-fast bacillus.
  • Most commonly occurs in middle-aged men.
  • Classically presents with arthralgias, weight loss, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • Central nervous system and cardiac involvement is common and occur later in the disease.
  • The intestinal lesion is also characterized by PAS-positive macrophages, that fills the lamina propria.

Figure showing H and E staining of the jejunum, where the lamina propria is replaced by foamy macrophages. The PAS staining will be positive in the macrophages as shown below:

Treatment is with a prolonged course of antibiotics, optimal regimen is uncertain.

  • Penicillin + streptomycin for 2 weeks, followed by 1 year of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman presents to the Emergency department with palpitations and shortness of breath. Recent thyroid function tests on the hospital computer reveal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) of <0.05 mU/l and a markedly elevated T4. You advise for blood gas testing.
Which of the following findings would be most consistent with Grave's disease?
questions.solution:
• Graves disease is a hypermetabolic disorder
  • Hypermetabolic disorder elevates basal metabolic rate, impacting organ function.
  • Respiratory effects include increased breathing rate and depth, leading to excessive carbon dioxide washout.
  • This carbon dioxide washout results in respiratory alkalosis due to decreased blood CO2 levels.
  • Compared with normal subjects, hyperthyroid patients show significantly lower resting arterial CO2 tension, tidal volume and significantly higher mean inspiratory flow and pa(O2).
  • This may of course lead to misdiagnosis of patients with hyperthyroidism as having hyperventilation syndrome.
  • Patients with hyperthyroidism also show a greater ventilatory response to hypoxia than normal patients. These ventilatory changes are significantly correlated with T3 levels

Small cell lung cancer also known as oat cell cancer
Squamous cell carcinoma is most common type of NSCLC

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding lung cancer except?
questions.solution:
• Pathological types : For practical purposes, lung cancers are divided into small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which are seen in a ratio of about 1:4.
  • The pattern of disease, the prognosis and the results of treatment for small cell (also known as oat cell) carcinoma differ from all other types sufficiently for these to be managed differently from the outset on the basis of the histological classification.
  • Subdivisions of NSCLC according to histological characteristics are much less important, but pathological staging is critical to treatment and outcome.
  • Histological classification of lung cancer:
  • Small cell lung cancers were known as oat cell cancers because of the packed nature or present as small dense cells. They area type of neuroendocrine tumour (NET) and about 20% of all lung cancers. They tend to metastasis early to lymph nodes and by blood-borne spread. The median survival is measured in months. The tumours are very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled (although it is still short) but they are rarely, if ever, cured. Surgery is rarely offered unless in very limited stage disease.
  • Adenocarcinoma is now the most common of the NSCLC types, having overtaken squamous cancer. The increasing incidence is partly due to an increasing incidence in women and may be the result, in part, of a move towards lower-tar cigarettes that are inhaled more deeply to get the same effect.
  • Squamous carcinoma typically appears as a cavitating tumour.
  • Large cell undifferentiated is a discrete histological type of NSCLCand is included within NETs.

choices.text: Prothrombin time (PT) and International Normalized Ratio (INR)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2, at 32 weeks of gestation presents with a history of recurrent miscarriage and thrombophilia. She has been prescribed Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) for thromboprophylaxis. What is the most important monitoring parameter while she is on LMWH?
questions.solution:
LMWH primarily works by inhibiting Factor Xa, and Anti-Xa activity levels are used to monitor the effectiveness of therapy. Unlike unfractionated heparin, LMWH has more predictable pharmacokinetics, but monitoring Anti-Xa activity helps ensure therapeutic levels and minimize the risk of bleeding or clotting complications.

  • a) Prothrombin time (PT) and International Normalized Ratio (INR): PT/INR is used to monitor Vitamin K antagonists like warfarin, not LMWH.
  • b) Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT): aPTT is typically used to monitor unfractionated heparin therapy and is not as reliable for LMWH monitoring due to its shorter half-life and more predictable effects.
  • c) Platelet count and haemoglobin levels: While important for monitoring potential side effects like heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), they are not the primary parameters for monitoring LMWH therapy.

choices.text: Best diagnostic test for unilateral stress fracture is MRI
Best diagnostic test for bilateral stress fracture is bone scan
They are often associated with repetitive loading and overuse.
They typically involve complete fractures with significant displacement.

questions.text: A young military recruit had complain of severe pain following 1 month of extensive training. Choose the false statement about stress fractures?
questions.solution:
Stress fractures are small fractures in a bone that develop due to repetitive mechanical loading and overuse, typically in athletes, military recruits, or individuals undergoing intense physical activity.

Key Features of Stress Fractures:

  1. Mechanism:
    • Unlike acute fractures caused by high-energy trauma, stress fractures result from repetitive stress exceeding the bone’s ability to repair and remodel itself.
  2. Risk Factors:
    • Common in people engaging in repetitive impact activities like running, jumping, or marching.
    • Risk is higher in individuals with sudden increases in physical activity or inadequate recovery times.
  3. Sites:
    • Frequently involve weight-bearing bones such as the tibia, metatarsals, and femur.
  4. Clinical Presentation:
    • Gradual onset of pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest.
  5. Radiographic Features:
    • Early stress fractures may not be visible on X-rays but can be detected with MRI or bone scans.

MRI - is the IOC for unilateral chest fractures

Bone scan - IOC for bilateral stress fractures

General orthopaedics and basic sciences

questions.text: A neonate presented with jaundice. No other findings were present. On doing an USG, a cystic lesion was found adjacent to the common bile duct. The image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The question describes a neonate with jaundice, and the ultrasound shows a cystic lesion adjacent to the common bile duct (CBD). Based on the image and clinical context, the correct diagnosis is B. Choledochal cyst, specifically Type II.
  • Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree. The Todani classification is used to categorize them:
    • Type I: Fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (most common).
    • Type II: A true diverticulum of the CBD.
    • Type III: Choledochocele (dilation within the duodenal wall).
    • Type IV: Multiple dilations of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts.
    • Type V: Caroli disease (intrahepatic ductal dilation).

Why Type II fits this case:

  • Location: The cyst is adjacent to the common bile duct, not within the liver or pancreas.
  • Shape: Appears as a small, saccular outpouching-classic for a diverticulum.
  • Presentation: Neonatal jaundice is a typical presentation.
  • Imaging: The USG shows a cystic lesion projecting from the CBD (pointed by arrows), which is consistent with Type II choledochal cyst.

questions.text: A 36 year old woman presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, diarrhoea and mouth ulcers. Full blood count reveals normocytic normochromic anaemia, inflammatory markers are raised, and biochemical investigation reveals a raised alkaline phosphatase. Barium follow through shows terminal ileal inflammatory disease. Long term remission may be maintained by the use of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Crohn's disease.

Remission of Crohn's disease may be achieved by the use of steroids, elemental diet, surgery or infliximab.

Mesalazine may maintain remission if induction has been achieved by surgery and if an 8-week course of metronidazole is administered. It has many side effects.

In other scenarios, the most useful drug to maintain long term remission is azathioprine.

Steroids (prednisolone) are only used for induction of remission. They are not appropriate for long term maintenance therapy.

Cyclosporine is used in severe cases of ulcerative colitis refractory to steroid therapy.

choices.text: Observe the patient with no further treatment

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy is given methotrexate. Her serum beta-hCG levels on day 4 show a 15% decrease from the initial value. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A 15% decrease in beta-hCG is a satisfactory response to methotrexate treatment. The next step is to continue monitoring the patient by repeating serum beta-hCG levels in 48 hours to ensure proper decline. If the levels continue to drop, expectant management can proceed.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Administer another dose of methotrexate:

Additional doses of methotrexate are only required if beta-hCG levels fail to decline by ≥15% between days 4 and 7.

B) Observe the patient with no further treatment:

While the initial response is favourable, continued monitoring is essential to confirm sustained decline and prevent complications.

C) Schedule the patient for surgery:

Surgery is reserved for cases of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, hemodynamic instability, or failure of medical management.

D) Repeat serum beta-hCG testing in another 48 hours (Correct):

This ensures that the patient is appropriately monitored to confirm resolution of the ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presented to the Ophthalmic Out patient department with complaints of right eye gradual, painless diminished vision since 1 year. On examination, there was white reflex in the pupillary area. The vision in right eye was PL+, PR full and hand movements present. All of the following is true about the given condition except?

questions.solution:
CPAP stands for Continuous Positive Airway Pressure. It is a type of non-invasive ventilation (NIV) where a constant and steady air pressure is delivered to keep the airways open - especially useful in patients with obstructive sleep apnoea, COPD, or during acute respiratory distress.


  • B. Invasive ventilation:
    Involves intubation with an endotracheal or tracheostomy tube. CPAP does not.
  • C. Controlled ventilation:
    Controlled ventilation delivers breaths at a preset rate and volume - CPAP requires patient effort and does not control the respiratory cycle.
  • D. Any of the above:
    Only option A is correct.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old is noted to have persistent polyuria in excess of 6 liters per day. She mentions recently being involved in an accident and sustained head injury which she thinks she has recovered from. Investigations reveal:
potassium 4.2 mmol/l
calcium 8.6 mg/dl
glucose 106 mg/dl
Serum osmolality : 290 mOsm/kg (280-295)
Urine osmolality : 192 mOsm/kg
Which one of the following is the best way of confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is likely to be diabetes insipidus.
  • The causes for polyuria in a patient include primary polydipsia, central DI and Nephrogenic DI
  • Diagnosis of DI in a patient with polyuria (urine output more than 50 ml/kg) is suggested by high plasma osmolality (>295 mOsm/kg) in a patient passing dilute urine ( urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg).
  • If the diagnostic thresholds of DI are not met, DI can be confirmed by a water deprivation test where failure of urine concentration would be expected. During this test a patient is not allowed to drink and plasma ADH, plasma osmolality and urine osmolality are measured.
  • A therapeutic trial of DDAVP is only appropriate if a diagnosis of DI is confirmed (On the water deprivation test) and helps to differentiate between cranial or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: All of the following nerves pass through the inguinal canal except:
questions.solution:
• The testis proceeds medially and downwards along the inguinal canal. Anterior to the canal is the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle, the fibres of which run downwards and medially.
  • The testis finally emerges through a V-shaped defect in the aponeurosis, the superficial inguinal ring, and descends into the scrotum.
  • The inguinal canal is roofed by the conjoint tendon, its posterior wall is transversalis fascia, an anterior wall is the external oblique aponeurosis and a floor, which is also the external oblique, that rolls inwards at its lower margin and thickens to become the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament.
  • The inguinal canal in males contains the testicular artery, veins, lymphatics and the vas deferens.
  • In females, the round ligament descends through the canal to end in the vulva.
  • Three important nerves, the ilioinguinal, the iliohypogastric and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, also pass through the canal.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Medial epicondyle -

  • The medial epicondyle is a prominent bony projection on the medial aspect of lower end of humerus.
  • It is sub-cutaneous and can be easily felt on the lower end of humerus.
  • It serves as a common origin point of superficial flexor muscles of forearm called as the 'common flexor origin'.

Radial head -

  • It is disc shaped and covered with hyaline cartilage.
  • It is concave superiorly and articulates with capitulum of humerus.
  • The circumference of the head is also articular and sit in the radial notch of ulna to form the superior radio-ulnar joint.

Capitulum -

  • It is a rounder projection in the lower end of humerus which articulates with the radial head.

Lateral epicondyle -

  • It is smaller than medial epicondyle. It serves as origin point for extensor muscles of forearm called the 'common extensor origin'.

General orthopaedics and basic sciences

questions.text: Sugammadex is a reversal agent that can be used for:
questions.solution:
• Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically developed to reverse neuromuscular blockade caused by certain aminosteroid non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Sugammadex is a modified γ-cyclodextrin.
  • It works by encapsulating free molecules of the neuromuscular blocker (especially rocuronium and vecuronium) in the plasma.
  • This reduces the available drug at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing the blockade.

Drugs Effectively Reversed by Sugammadex:


Why Not Neostigmine Here?

  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and acts less rapidly and predictably than Sugammadex.
  • Sugammadex has faster and more complete reversal, especially after profound blockade with rocuronium or vecuronium.

questions.solution: The case scenario suggests rheumatoid arthritis. 4% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis develop bronchiectasis. Other causes are chronic infection (TB, measles, whooping cough etc), foreign body aspiration, hypogammaglobulinemia, Kartagener's syndrome, Young's syndrome, cystic fibrosis, allergic Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

questions.text: A 35 year old man whose condition has suddenly deteriorated is brought to ER. He had arrived 30 minutes earlier with a 2-hour history of central pleuritic chest pain and breathlessness. He collapsed while awaiting CXR. He is cyanosed and has a pulse 130/min and BP of 85/45 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is reading 81%, despite high flow oxygen via a re-breathe mask. Respiratory examination reveals reduced breath sounds in the right lung field with deviation of the trachea towards the left. What immediate course of action should be taken?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is a right sided spontaneous pneumothorax, which has now developed into a tension pneumothorax.
  • As the patient is unstable, there is no time to arrange for a portable chest XR, insertion of a large bore needle would reduce the pressure in the right hemithorax.
  • Mechanical ventilation at this stage would be detrimental as additional positive pressure would be transmitted to the mediastinum causing a further reduction in venous return and cardiac output
  • Large right sided pneumothorax

Cardinal features of a Tension pneumothorax:

  • Enlarged hemithorax
  • Absent air entry
  • Deviation of mediastinum to the contralateral side
  • Hyper resonance
  • Hypotension
  • Raised JVP

questions.text: A 3-day boy comes to you with mother complaining that child has not passed stool since birth. The abdomen is distended and he has stopped taking feeds since morning. questions.text: A young male with a history of drug abuse is brought to casualty in an altered state. His 8-year-old sister has ADHD. His parents show an empty pill bottle that he might have taken. Which of the following is likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A young male possibly ingested ADHD medication (belonging to his sister). ADHD is commonly treated with CNS stimulants, primarily:

  • Methylphenidate
  • Amphetamines (like lisdexamfetamine)
  • Modafinil (less commonly in children, more in adults/narcolepsy)

These drugs increase dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, leading to sympathetic nervous system stimulation.

Expected Symptoms of CNS Stimulant Overdose:

Stimulant overdose mimics sympathomimetic toxidrome, presenting with:

  • Tachycardia (↑ HR)
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperthermia
  • Mydriasis (not miosis)
  • Agitation, anxiety, altered mental status
  • Seizures (in severe cases)

So, tachycardia is the most likely feature among the given options.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorbike accident. He complains of severe pain in his right thigh. On examination, there is significant swelling and deformity in the mid-thigh region. Distal pulses are intact, and sensation in the foot is preserved. The orthopedician decides to apply a Thomas splint during initial management. What is the primary purpose of applying a Thomas splint in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Thomas Splint

  • The Thomas splint is used for immobilization of fractures, especially those involving the femur.
  • It provides traction to align the fractured bone and reduces pain by preventing movement.
  • It is primarily used as an initial stabilizing measure before definitive surgical treatment.

Key Functions:

  1. Reduces pain by limiting motion.
  2. Prevents further injury to surrounding tissues, blood vessels, and nerves.
  3. Minimizes the risk of complications like fat embolism or shock.
  4. Facilitates safe transport of the patient.

Misconceptions in Other Options:

  • B: The Thomas splint provides temporary stabilization, not rigid fixation.
  • C: It is not a definitive treatment; it is a temporary measure before surgery.
  • D: While it may indirectly help reduce swelling, its primary purpose is immobilization and pain relief.

General trauma

questions.text: Which of the following radiological features is characteristic of Perthes disease?
questions.solution:
Perthes disease is an osteochondritis of the epiphysis of the femoral head caused by partial or complete avascular necrosis. The condition primarily affects boys aged 5-10 years and is characterized by a tri-phasic progression:

  1. Stage of Synovitis - Initial inflammation and pain.
  2. Stage of Trabecular Necrosis - Bone necrosis and structural weakening.
  3. Stage of Healing - Gradual revascularization and repair.

Etiology:

While the exact cause is unknown, recurrent episodes of ischemia of the femoral head, possibly triggered by episodes of synovitis, are believed to be the underlying mechanism.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Pain in the hip, often radiating to the knee.
    • Limping or hip stiffness.
  • Examination findings:
    • Limited abduction and internal rotation.
    • Occasional shortening of the affected limb.

Radiological Features:

  • Early collapse and sclerosis of the femoral head epiphysis.
  • Widened hip joint space.
  • Bone scan may reveal decreased uptake in the femoral head.
  • A striking contrast often exists between minimal clinical findings and gross radiological changes
  • Crescent sign - Sclerosis - Fragmentation- Complete collapse

Prognostic Classification:

  • The Catterall classification categorizes Perthes disease into four groups based on the extent of femoral head involvement.
  • Head-at-risk signs, such as lateral subluxation of the femoral head or calcification lateral to the epiphysis, indicate a poorer prognosis.

Treatment Goals:

  • Preventing mis-shaping of the femoral head during the softening phase.
  • Head containment within the acetabulum is essential to allow proper revascularization.

Treatment Options:

  1. Conservative methods:
    • Plaster casts or splints to maintain containment.
  2. Surgical intervention:
    • Containment osteotomy to realign the femoral head within the acetabulum.

Timely diagnosis and appropriate management are critical to prevent long-term complications such as hip deformity or osteoarthritis.

Pediatric orthopaedics

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with a single, painless, indurated genital ulcer since 1 week. He had a history of unprotected intercourse one month ago. What is the treatment administered?
questions.solution:
• Painless indurated ulcer is a pointer for Syphilis
  • Next step of investigation - Darkfield microscopy
  • Motility- Corkscrew
  • Treatment - Benzathine penicillin

  • Primary syphilis is characterized by a solitary, painless genital ulcer (chancre) and painless lymphadenopathy.
  • The indurated nature of the ulcer and the timeline following unprotected intercourse support this diagnosis, with an incubation period of 9-90 days.

Other options

  1. Aciclovir- Used in the treatment of Herpes
  2. Azithromycin- Used in the treatment of Chancroid, Donovanosis
  3. Doxycycline- Used in the treatment of LGV

Tag:

  • Primary Syphilis

Key takeaway

  • Solitary, painless indurated genital ulcer
  • Painless lymphadenopathi
  • IP: 9-90 days

questions.text: A 55 year old gentleman has pickwickian syndrome. He has poor exercise tolerance of 50 yards and often feels lethargic at work. Which of the following is the best investigation?
questions.solution:
• The classic features of Pickwickian syndrome or obesity hypoventilation syndrome are obesity and daytime hypercapnia.
  • The differences between Pickwickian syndrome and OSA are that former has longer and more continuous episodes of hypoventilation overnight (there may or may not be upper airway obstruction).
  • The diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnoea can be made with a sleep study (polysomnography). In sleep apnoea, there is gross obesity and airways obstruction, occasionally leading to type II respiratory failure. During the sleep study, > 10 episodes of apnoeic episodes (pauses in breathing) satisfies the criteria for obstructive sleep apnoea.
  • A sleep study is the gold standard test for diagnosing OSA. It involves monitoring the patient's breathing, heart rate, and oxygen levels during sleep. The sleep study will also show the number and duration of apneas and hypopneas (breathing pauses).
  • The other options are not as accurate for diagnosing Pickwickian syndrome.
  • Echocardiography can be used to assess cor pulmonale, which is a heart condition that can develop in people with Pickwickian syndrome. However, it is not the best test for diagnosing the condition.
  • CT scan of the chest can be used to visualize the lungs and airways, but it is not as sensitive as a sleep study for detecting OSA.
  • Blood gas can be used to measure the levels of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood, but it is not as specific as a sleep study for diagnosing Pickwickian syndrome.

questions.text: 11 years old child with rheumatic fever has fever and sore throat. His heart evaluation was normal. How long should he receive Benzathine penicillin prophylaxis?
Which of the following is found in subjects acclimatized to high altitudes?
questions.solution:
This question deals with a person who is already acclimatized to a high altitude.

There are two responses to high altitude

A normal initial 'struggle response' to such an ascent includes increased ventilation-the cornerstone of acclimatization-mediated by the carotid bodies. Hyperventilation may cause respiratory alkalosis and dehydration. Respiratory alkalosis may be extreme, with an arterial blood pH of >7.7 (e.g., at the summit of Everest). Alkalosis may depress the ventilatory drive during sleep, with consequent periodic breathing and hypoxemia.

So periodic breathing occurs in people who are yet to acclimatize.

Once the individual gets acclimatized there will be increased sympathetic tone; increased erythropoietin levels, leading to increased hemoglobin levels and red blood cell mass; increased tissue capillary density and mitochondrial numbers; and higher levels of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate, enhancing oxygen utilization, increased cardiac output and pulmonary artery pressure.

questions.text: Which among the following is the possible complication of pancreatic pseudocyst due to enlargement of the cyst?
Which among the following is not an indication for surgical therapy in treatment of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
• Surgical treatment.
  • Although medical management is indicated during acute exacerbations of disease, most patients with chronic Crohn disease will require surgery at some time during the course of their illness.
  • The goals are to preserve bowel length while minimizing postoperative complications and disease recurrence
  • Approximately 70% of patients will require surgical resection within 15 years after diagnosis
  • Indications for surgery include failure of medical treatment, bowel obstruction, fistula or abscess formation, steroid dependence, dysplasia or malignancy
  • Most patients can be treated with elective surgery, especially with the improvement of medical management in the past decade. However, patients with intestinal perforation, peritonitis, excessive bleeding, or toxic megacolon require urgent surgery

questions.text: A gardener with history of thorn prick presents with lesion as shown below. What will be the histopathological hallmark of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Asteroid bodies are a hallmark of Sporotrichosis, a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii.

This fungus is often introduced through puncture wounds (e.g., from a thorn prick) and causes a characteristic lymphocutaneous infection, where the lesion spreads linearly along the lymphatic channels.

Histopathological feature: Asteroid bodies are large, star-shaped structures seen in the cytoplasm of macrophages in tissue sections infected with Sporothrix schenckii.

Asteroid bodies are the histopathological hallmark of Sporotrichosis.

Option A- Schaumann bodies

  • Explanation: These are inclusion bodies seen in granulomas of sarcoidosis, HSP, Berryliyosis

Option B - Copper penny body

Chromoblastomycosis, a chronic fungal infection caused by different species of fungi like Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora, and Phialophora.

  • Histology: Thick-walled, dark, and rounded bodies seen, known as Sclerotic bodies or Copper penny bodies.

Option C- Mallor bodies are seen in alcoholic steatohepatitis

Key takeaway: Asteroid body is the correct option, as it is the histopathological hallmark associated with Sporotrichosis, which is consistent with the patient's presentation of a linear spread of lesions following a thorn prick.

choices.text: Lumbar spinal stenosis; conservative management with physical therapy
Prolapsed intervertebral disc (PIVD); conservative management followed by surgical intervention if symptoms persist

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of lower back pain radiating down his right leg. The pain is sharp and worsens with coughing and sneezing. He reports numbness and tingling in his right foot. On physical examination, there is positive straight leg raise test at 40 degrees on the right side and weakness in dorsiflexion of the right foot. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended management?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation (lower back pain radiating down the leg, positive straight leg raise test and weakness) is consistent with Prolapsed Intervertebral Disc (PIVD), also known as a herniated disc.

Management of PIVD:

Conservative Treatment for PIVD:

  1. Rest: Essential for 2-4 days, preferably on a hard bed.
  2. Medications:
    • Analgesics for pain relief.
    • Muscle relaxants to alleviate muscle spasms.
  3. Physiotherapy:
    • Hot fomentation and gentle arching exercises.
  4. Other modalities:
    • Lumbar traction and Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS).

Operative Treatment for PIVD:

Indications:

  • Failure of conservative treatment.
  • Cauda equina syndrome.
  • Severe sciatic tilt.

Surgical Techniques:

  1. Fenestration:
    • Removal of the ligamentum flavum to expose the spinal canal at the affected level.
  2. Laminotomy:
    • Addition of a hole in the lamina for wider exposure.
  3. Hemi-laminectomy:
    • Removal of the lamina on one side for better access.
  4. Laminectomy:
    • Removal of the laminae and spinous process on both sides, often for large central discs causing cauda equina syndrome.

Note: Early intervention and appropriate follow-up are important to prevent chronic pain or neurological deficits.

Spinal pathologies and injuries

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is reporting in OPD that he is suffering from diabetes mellitus. On asking how he knows about his condition, he is replying that his friend has stolen his pancreas. This can be considered as.
questions.solution:
The question describes a delusional belief where the patient thinks his pancreas has been stolen, which is a classic example of a nihilistic delusion - a hallmark feature of Cotard’s syndrome.

  1. De Clérambault syndrome - Erotomania: delusion that someone (often of higher status) is in love with the patient.
  2. Othello syndrome - Delusional jealousy: belief that partner is unfaithful.
  3. Bobbitt syndrome - Not a recognized psychiatric syndrome in standard texts like Kaplan or DSM; it is sometimes used colloquially but not medically.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Phytophotodermatitis?
questions.solution:
Option C. It is responsible for Chronic actinic dermatitis:

  • This statement is not true. Chronic actinic dermatitis is a different condition characterized by photosensitivity to sunlight, often seen in elderly individuals with a history of sun exposure. Phytophotodermatitis involves a reaction to plant chemicals when exposed to sunlight, but it does not cause chronic actinic dermatitis. The term actinic refers to sun and there is no relation with plants

Option A. Parthenium is the most common plant responsible:

  • This statement is true. Parthenium hysterophorus is a common cause of phytophotodermatitis, especially in India.

Option B. Sesquiterpene lactone is an allergen:

  • This is also true. Sesquiterpene lactones found in certain plants can trigger allergic reactions.

Option D. It is Type 4 hypersensitivity:

  • This statement is true. Phytophotodermatitis is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity).

Key Takeaway:

Phytophotodermatitis is a skin condition caused by the interaction of certain plant substances (furocoumarins) with ultraviolet (UV) light, leading to dermatitis.

Parthenium hysterophorus is a common cause of phytophotodermatitis, especially in India.

Phytophotodermatitis is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity).

Sesquiterpene lactones found in certain plants can trigger allergic reactions.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a sudden and severe episode of headache. No precipitating factor was identified. Except for mild neck stiffness, general physical and neurological examinations were unremarkable. On admission, a computed tomography (CT) scan showed a thin collection of blood on the right sylvian cistern, establishing the diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The admitting doctor is considering further management. Which of the Following medications have been shown to decrease the incidence of cerebral infarction in patients with subarachnoid haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The medical management of SAH focuses on protecting the air way, managing blood pressure before and after aneurysm treatment, preventing rebleeding prior to treatment, managing vasospasm and Delayed Cerebral Ischemia(DCI), treating hydrocephalus, treating hyponatremia, limiting secondary brain insults, and preventing pulmonary embolus (PE).

DCI remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality following aneurysmal SAH. Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, perhaps by preventing ischemic injury rather than reducing the risk of vasospasm.

Osmotic agents can worsen the cerebral perfusion and can worsen ischemia and hence should be given only to those with features of raised ICP.

Vasopressors and hydration also helps to prevent cerebral ischemia.

Steroids may be used to reduce head and neck pain caused by blood in the sub arachnoid space. It does not reduce cerebral ischemia and is hence not routinely recommended.

So the most appropriate answer is Nimodipine

questions.text: Which among the following is not a useful investigation modality for diagnosing capsular invasion in a case of follicular adenoma?
questions.solution:
• Benign tumors: Follicular adenomas present as clinically solitary nodules and the distinction between a follicular carcinoma and an adenoma can only be made by histological examination; in the adenoma there is no invasion of the capsule or of pericapsular blood vessels.
  • For this reason, FNA, which provides cytological detail but not tissue architecture, cannot differentiate between benign and malignant follicular lesions.
  • Diagnosis and treatment is therefore, by wide excision, i.e. total lobectomy.
  • The remaining thyroid tissue is normal so that prolonged follow-up is unnecessary.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of two second-trimester losses is found to have a short cervix on transvaginal ultrasound. She is at 14 weeks of gestation. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The patient in this case has a history of second-trimester pregnancy losses, which is suggestive of cervical insufficiency. Additionally, she is found to have a short cervix on transvaginal ultrasound at 14 weeks of gestation. This combination of factors makes her a candidate for cervical cerclage to prevent further preterm losses.

Option-wise Explanation:

  1. Bed rest and progesterone therapy:
    • While bed rest and progesterone therapy may help reduce the risk of preterm labor in some situations, they are not the first-line treatments for a short cervix with a history of second-trimester losses due to suspected cervical insufficiency.
    • Progesterone has been shown to reduce the risk of preterm birth in women with a short cervix, but cerclage is the more effective intervention in cases of significant cervical shortening (≤2.5 cm) or a history of recurrent losses.
    • Evidence: Studies show that cerclage is more effective than progesterone or bed rest in preventing preterm birth in patients with cervical insufficiency or a short cervix.
  2. Cervical cerclage at 14 weeks (Correct):
    • Cervical cerclage is indicated for women with a short cervix (<25 mm) and a history of second-trimester pregnancy loss or preterm birth due to cervical insufficiency. The optimal time for cerclage placement is between 12-14 weeks of gestation.
    • Procedure: The cerclage is placed around the cervix to prevent it from opening prematurely and to hold the pregnancy in place. It is typically removed between 36-38 weeks of gestation or when labor begins.
    • Evidence: According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), women with a history of preterm birth or second-trimester losses due to cervical insufficiency and a short cervix are at high risk for further pregnancy loss or preterm birth and benefit from cerclage.
    • Outcome: The cerclage significantly reduces the risk of preterm birth and pregnancy loss in these patients.
  3. Regular antenatal visits and ultrasound monitoring:
    • While regular monitoring with ultrasounds is important for managing high-risk pregnancies, this alone is not sufficient to manage a short cervix in a patient with a history of recurrent second-trimester losses.
    • Explanation: Monitoring alone does not address the mechanical issue of cervical insufficiency. Cervical cerclage is the definitive treatment for patients with a short cervix and a history of pregnancy loss due to cervical insufficiency.
  4. Expectant management:
    • Expectant management (i.e., no intervention) is not appropriate in this case because the patient has already experienced two second-trimester losses, and her cervix is now found to be short on ultrasound. The risk of another second-trimester loss or preterm birth is high, and therefore, active intervention (cerclage) is required.
    • Explanation: Expectant management is generally reserved for women who have no previous history of second-trimester losses and whose cervix is found to be short only later in pregnancy (usually after 20 weeks), but not for those with a prior history of cervical insufficiency or loss.

Topic: Cervical Cerclage

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman in her third trimester presents with sudden dyspnea, hypotension, and tachycardia after a spontaneous rupture of membranes. She becomes unresponsive and requires immediate resuscitation. The most likely cause of her symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but life-threatening complication that can occur during labor, delivery, or shortly after the rupture of membranes. It typically presents with sudden onset of dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia, and loss of consciousness. The condition is caused when amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enters the maternal bloodstream, triggering a severe systemic reaction, including respiratory and cardiovascular collapse.

  • a) Amniotic fluid embolism: The sudden onset of dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia, and unresponsiveness following spontaneous rupture of membranes is highly suggestive of AFE. Immediate resuscitation is essential, and rapid delivery of the fetus is often required.
  • b) Acute asthma exacerbation: Asthma exacerbations can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, but they are usually not associated with sudden hypotension or unresponsiveness. The clinical scenario here is more consistent with AFE.
  • c) Vasovagal syncope: Although vasovagal syncope can cause hypotension and loss of consciousness, it typically occurs with triggers such as pain or prolonged standing, and does not cause sudden severe respiratory distress or tachycardia.
  • d) Acute peripartum cardiomyopathy: This is a form of heart failure that can occur during pregnancy or shortly after delivery, but it typically develops over a period of days to weeks, rather than presenting acutely after rupture of membranes.

The clinical presentation, including the timing following rupture of membranes, makes amniotic fluid embolism the most likely diagnosis.

Topic: Amniotic fluid embolism

choices.text: Secondary glaucoma due to hypertension; oral beta-blockers

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male presents with gradual vision loss in both eyes. He reports no pain or redness in the eyes. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 26 mmHg in both eyes, and the optic discs show signs of cupping. The visual field test reveals peripheral vision loss. The patient has a family history of glaucoma. His medical history is significant for hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication.
Question: Based on this case, what is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG)

Overview:

  • POAG is a chronic, bilateral, and asymmetrical condition.
  • Characterized by:
    • Open anterior chamber angle
    • Optic nerve head changes
    • Visual field damage
    • Intraocular pressure (IOP) >21 mmHg

Prevalence:

  • Common in Caucasians, Africans, and Asians.
  • Occurs more frequently in adults, typically after 40 years.
  • Genetic component with multifactorial inheritance.

Types:

  • Normal Tension Glaucoma: IOP <21 mmHg, but features of POAG present.
  • Ocular Hypertension: IOP >21 mmHg without optic nerve or field abnormalities.
  • POAG Suspects: Optic nerve changes without raised IOP or visual field changes.

Pathogenesis:

  • Increased resistance to aqueous outflow at the trabecular meshwork, especially in the juxtacanalicular region.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, but patients may report:
    • Headache
    • Visual changes (e.g., scotoma)
    • Difficulty adapting to darkness
  • Signs:
    • Raised IOP (>21 mmHg) or circadian variation
    • Optic nerve changes (e.g., cup-to-disc ratio >0.5)
    • Visual field defects
    • Retinal nerve fibre layer defects

Management:

  • Medical Therapy:
    • Start with prostaglandin analogues or beta-blockers.
    • Laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) as an effective first-line treatment.
  • Surgical Options:
    • Trabeculectomy is the most common.
    • Glaucoma drainage devices and non-penetrating surgeries are also used.
    • Phacoemulsification may reduce IOP in patients with lens opacity.

Prognosis:

  • Most patients do not go blind, but the risk increases with late diagnosis and poor treatment adherence.
  • Lifetime blindness risk: 5-10% in Caucasians.
  • Improved prognosis with newer treatments.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a twin pregnancy at 36 weeks presents in labour. During the delivery of the first twin, fetal heart rate decelerations are noted, and the second twin is in a transverse lie. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
When fetal distress occurs during the first twin's delivery, and the second twin is in transverse lie, a cesarean section is usually indicated. Transverse lie can complicate vaginal delivery, and if the first twin shows signs of fetal distress, prompt surgical delivery is warranted.

Option wise analysis:

In twin pregnancies, management of the second twin is crucial, especially when complications arise during the delivery of the first twin. Here's why:

  • a) Attempt vaginal delivery of the second twin with rotation: Vaginal delivery of a transverse lie twin is very challenging and carries high risks of injury to the fetus and mother. Attempting vaginal delivery in this situation is not advisable.
  • b) Immediate cesarean section for the second twin: A transverse lie is an indication for cesarean section, as it presents a high risk of cord prolapse, fetal injury, and failure of vaginal delivery. If the first twin's delivery is complicated by fetal distress, cesarean section for the second twin is often the safest option.
  • c) Wait for spontaneous delivery of the second twin: Waiting for the second twin to spontaneously deliver in transverse lie is not recommended, as it can lead to serious complications for both the mother and the fetus.
  • d) Manual rotation of the second twin followed by vaginal delivery: Although manual rotation may be attempted in some cases of non-vertex lies (like breech), it is less likely to be successful with a transverse lie, and there is still a significant risk of complications. If the first twin's delivery is complicated, a cesarean is generally the preferred approach.

In this case, immediate cesarean section is the best course of action due to the transverse lie and fetal distress in the first twin.

Topic: Management of twins in labour

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with painful, recurrent genital lesions and a history of similar episodes. Laboratory testing confirms the presence of herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 2. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The first-line treatment for genital herpes involves oral antiviral medications such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir. Topical treatment is less effective for genital herpes. Intravenous acyclovir is reserved for severe or disseminated infections.

The treatment of genital herpes caused by HSV type 2 primarily involves oral antiviral medications. The first-line options include:

  • Acyclovir (oral)
  • Valacyclovir (oral)
  • Famciclovir (oral)

These oral antivirals are effective in reducing the severity and duration of an outbreak, and they help decrease the frequency of recurrent episodes. They also play a role in reducing viral shedding, thus lowering the risk of transmission to others.

Other Options:

  • B) Topical acyclovir: Topical acyclovir is generally less effective than oral antiviral treatment for genital herpes. It may provide some symptom relief but does not significantly reduce the duration of the outbreak.
  • C) Oral antibiotics: Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections, not viral infections like genital herpes. They are ineffective against HSV.
  • D) Intravenous acyclovir: IV acyclovir is reserved for severe cases of HSV infection, such as neonatal herpes, disseminated infections, or HSV encephalitis. For this patient with recurrent but not severe genital lesions, oral acyclovir is appropriate.

Summary:

  • Acyclovir (oral) is the first-line treatment for genital HSV-2.
  • Topical acyclovir is less effective for genital herpes.
  • Oral antibiotics are not effective against viral infections like HSV.
  • Intravenous acyclovir is reserved for severe infections.

Topic: Management of genital herpes in pregnancy

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) - Genital Herpes: Treatment and Management

questions.text: Which imaging technique is most commonly used to diagnose osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Imaging of Osteomyelitis

Radiographs- earliest change can be detected in 24-48 hours (soft tissue edema, separation of fascial planes) - NON SPECIFIC

  • Acute Osteomyelitis:
    • Soft tissue swelling
    • Bone demineralization or regional osteopenia (≈2 weeks after infection)
  • Chronic Osteomyelitis:
    • Periosteal reaction - best change in x-ray, but occurs in 7-10 days
    • Cortical erosions
    • Bony lucency and sclerotic changes
    • Bony lysis around hardware and prosthetic joints
  • Sequestra: Dead bone nidus with surrounding granulation tissue
  • Involucrum: Periosteal new bone formation later

MRI

  • Best method to show early osteomyelitis and anatomic location
  • Penumbra sign:
    • Bright signal in surrounding bone
    • Darker abscess and sclerotic bone
  • Negative finding rules out osteomyelitis
  • Positive finding may overestimate the extent of the disease

Fluorodeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography (FDG-PET)

  • Shows malignancies and infections (increased glycolysis)
  • Most sensitive test for chronic osteomyelitis
  • More specific than MRI or bone scan

Bone infections

questions.text:
A 47 year old man was referred for assessment of unsteady gait, which has been present for 6 months. He has lost a stone in weight over the several months. An MRI of the brain shows multiple high signal areas. A biopsy was taken of one of the lesions. The report shows perivascular infiltrates of lymphocytes affecting white and gray matter. There was minimal myelin loss. CSF examination shows raised white cell count, and oligoclonal bands were not raised.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The white matter lesions suggest either multiple sclerosis or lymphoma. Infiltration with lymphocytes can be seen in Multiple Sclerosis too. In around 10% of patients with MS, OCB can be absent.

However, the presence of perivascular lymphocyte infiltrates is classical of CNS lymphoma and constitutional symptoms makes the diagnosis of CNS lymphoma more likely.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of temporal lobe epilepsy?
questions.solution:
• These seizures usually last 1-2 min and are often preceded by an aura.
  • Subsequent manifestations consist of decreased responsiveness, staring, looking around seemingly purposelessly, and automatisms. Automatisms are automatic semi-purposeful movements of the mouth (oral, alimentary such as chewing) or of the extremities (manual, such as manipulating the sheets; leg automatisms such as shuffling, walking).
  • After the seizure, the patient can have postictal automatisms, sleepiness, and/or other transient focal deficits such as weakness (Todd paralysis) or aphasia.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical tests is used to assess ulnar nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Froment's sign is used to assess ulnar nerve palsy. In this test, the patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. A positive sign occurs if the thumb flexes at the interphalangeal joint (using the flexor pollicis longus, innervated by the median nerve) instead of adducting, indicating weakness of the adductor pollicis, a muscle supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Mnemonic for Ulnar Nerve Examination: BCDEF of Music

  • B - Book Test (Option B) : A diagnostic test to assess ulnar nerve function.
  • C - Card Test (Option A) : Another test used to evaluate the integrity of interossie muscles.
  • D - ADductor Pollicis Paralysis: Assessing for paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • E - Egawa Test (Option D) : A specific test for ulnar nerve function.
  • F - Froment's Sign: A clinical sign indicating ulnar nerve dysfunction, typically observed during pinching tasks.
  • Music - Musician's Nerve: A mnemonic reference indicating the ulnar nerve’s significance, often referred to as the “musician’s nerve” due to its crucial role in hand function.

A) Phalen's test evaluates median nerve compression in carpal tunnel syndrome.

C) Tinel's sign assesses nerve injury (not specific)

D) Adson's test is used to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome.

Nerve injuries and neuropathies

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman with Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents to the clinic for review. She is managed with thyroxine 125 mcg/day replacement. She presents to the clinic complaining of bilateral loin pain.
Investigations;Hb 12.1 g/dl
WCC 5.4 x 10^9/L
PLT 294 x 10^9/L
Na+ 139 mmol/l
K+ 3.3 mmol/l
Creatinine 1.40 mg/dl
HCO3- 15 mmol/l
KUB Evidence of nephrocalcinosis
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Among the conditions listed above, only RTA Type 1 is associated with metabolic acidosis with hypercalciuria.
  • Renal tubular acidosis is a group of disorder characterised by hyperchloremic normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Renal tubular acidosis Type 1 (distal renal tubular acidosis) may occur in association with a number of autoimmune conditions including SLE, vasculitis and autoimmune hypothyroidism. Other causes include drugs such as amphotericin B and lithium, inherited conditions such as Marfan's syndrome and conditions such as chronic pyelonephritis and obstructive uropathy. Treatment includes oral supplementation with potassium and bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 3 year old male patient presented with fluid filled lesions over abdomen and thighs since 2 months. Direct Immunofluorescence shows Linear deposition of IgA at basement membrane zone. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• It is subepidermal blistering disorder
  • Classic clinical presentation: Annular erythematous lesions with a ring of vesicles, commonly referred to as a "crown of jewels" or "string of pearls."
  • In children, the lesions most commonly occur on the abdomen, lower back, thighs, groin area, and around the eyes and mouth.
  • In adults, this disease is called Linear IgA dermatosis.
  • DIF- Linear deposition of IgA ab

The combination of age, clinical presentation, and immunofluorescence findings strongly indicates Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood as the most likely diagnosis.

Option A: Dermatitis Herpetiformis

  • Cause: Associated with gluten sensitivity.
  • Symptoms: Presents with grouped papules and vesicles primarily on extensor surfaces (knees, elbows, buttocks), often accompanied by severe itching.
  • DIF Findings: Shows IgA deposition in a granular pattern ("picket fence" appearance) in the papillary dermis, not linear at the basement membrane.

Option C: Bullous Pemphigoid

  • Population: Primarily affects elderly patients.
  • Symptoms: Begins with pruritic urticarial lesions that evolve into tense blisters on erythematous or normal skin.
  • Mucosal Involvement: Occurs in a minority of cases.
  • Histopathology: Shows subepidermal splitting with eosinophilic infiltrate, not the linear IgA deposition seen in this case
  • DIF - will show IgG deposition

Option D-Congenital Epidermolysis bullosa

DIF negative, IOC is Electron microscopy

Key takeaway:

Chronic bullous disease of childhood aka Linear IgA disease

  • Child + Bulla + Lower body - Think of Linear IgA disease
  • Direct Immunofluorescence will show linear IGA deposition at the basement membrane zone
  • It is subepidermal blistering disorder
  • Classic clinical presentation: "crown of jewels" or "string of pearls."
  • In adults, this disease is called Linear IgA dermatosis.
  • DIF- Linear deposition of IgA ab

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. He had two episodes of syncope and the ECG tracing during one such episode is given below. Coronary angiography showed a 99% LAD artery stenosis and angioplasty was unsuccessful due to the tortuosity of the vessel. Echocardiography shows a dilated LV at 5.9 cm with an ejection fraction of 28%. Which is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
The indications for Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD) include:

  • Patients with a history of sustained VT/VF not due to acute MI or any reversible cause.
  • History of previous MI and EF < 35% for NYHA Class II or III, EF < 30% for Class 1.
  • Familial or inherited condition with predisposition for VT/VF.

questions.text: A 45 year old diabetic patient presents with asymptomatic skin lesion as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Granuloma annulare (GA) is the most common non-infectious granulomatous disease.

  • Presentation: Typically appears as erythematous plaques or papules arranged in an annular (ring-like) configuration.
  • Location: Often found on the lateral and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet.
  • Usually asymptomatic,

Option A- Lupus vulgaris. Presents with central scarring.

Option C. Tinea corporis: Presents as annular erythematous itchy lesions with red, scaling, showing active margins and central clearing. This would usually be symptomatic.

Option D. Erythema annulare centrifugum: Characterized by annular, erythematous lesions that expand centrifugally and may have a trailing scale. It typically has a more inflammatory appearance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Granuloma annulare is a non-infectious condition often seen in patients with diabetes and characterized by its distinct annular appearance.
  • Location: Often found on the lateral and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet.
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Annular lesion, margin is skin colored and beaded, Center area shows normal skin

questions.text: A 31-year-old, gravida 1 para 0 woman vaginally delivers a 33-week estimated gestational age neonate at home. Upon arrival of emergency medical services, the neonate is grey and apneic. The heart rate is 70 beats/min. The neonate has been dried, stimulated, and suctioned without improvement. Of the following, the next BEST intervention is?
questions.solution:
• Bag-valve mask ventilation is the priority in newborns who need cardiorespiratory support after birth.
  • A rise in heart rate is the most important indicator of effective ventilation and response to resuscitative interventions.
  • Chest compressions are provided if there is a poor heart rate response to ventilation after appropriate ventilation is instituted.

Reference: Neonatal resuscitation program guidelines, AAP- 2022

questions.text: A 30-year-old asymptomatic woman, as part of her routine health checkup, underwent ECG testing which is shown below. Which of the following drugs should be started in her?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows bradycardia. The QT interval, ie, from the beginning of the Q wave to the end of T wave here is 5 large squares. One large square is 0.2 seconds. So here the QT interval is 1 second. The QT interval varies with the heart rate and hence it has to be corrected for the heart rate, which is called the corrected QT interval or QTc.

QTc=QT/square root of RR interval

So here the RR interval is 9 large squares. Which is 1.8 seconds.

So the corrected QT will be 1/square root of 1.8= 0.74

The normal QTc is 0.42 seconds.

So here the QT is prolonged.

So in an asymptomatic patient we should think of congenital long QT syndromes.

QT prolongation is associated with risk of ventricular arrhythmias.

Non selective beta blockers should be started in such patients to prevent ventricular arrhythmias. Hence the answer is propranolol

questions.text: A girl child is presented with stereotyped behavior, hand wringing and deceleration in head growth as per age. Which of the following is medication can be used in her condition?

questions.text: A 38-year-old male, known case of major depression. He has been taking anti-depressants for last 2 years. He is brought to emergency with complaints of palpitations, blurred vision, difficulty in passing urine. His ECG shows prolonged PR interval. Family members are reporting that he has consumed multiple pills. Which antidepressant can cause his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Amoxapine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). The patient has signs that are classic for TCA overdose, including:

  • Anticholinergic effects:
    • Blurred vision
    • Urinary retention (difficulty in passing urine)
    • Confusion (though not mentioned explicitly, commonly seen)
  • Cardiac effects:
    • Palpitations and prolonged PR interval on ECG
    • TCA overdose can lead to QRS widening, QT prolongation, and arrhythmias
  • CNS effects (not mentioned here but common):
    • Seizures
    • Coma

Investigations for TCA Toxicity

  1. ECG - Most crucial:
    • Widened QRS complex (>100 ms increases risk of seizures; >160 ms increases risk of arrhythmias)
    • Prolonged PR and QT intervals
    • Right axis deviation and terminal R wave in aVR
  2. Serum TCA levels - Not routinely used for diagnosis, but helpful in unclear cases
  3. Blood gases (ABG) - To detect metabolic acidosis
  4. Electrolytes - Monitor for abnormalities that could worsen cardiac toxicity (e.g., hypokalemia)
  5. Toxicology screen - To confirm exposure

Mainstay treatment: Sodium bicarbonate

REFERENCE: Katzung, B. G., Vanderah, T. W., & Trevor, A. J. (Eds.). (2021).

questions.text: Mr. Jack speaks a lot about his job and status. He wants everyone to talk about him only. Sometimes he becomes very arrogant. His behaves like a boss everywhere. And he can't take any criticism easily. Which of the following is wrong statement related to personality of Mr. Jack?
questions.solution:
Based on the description:

  • Talks excessively about job/status
  • Wants attention and admiration
  • Acts arrogantly
  • Behaves like a boss
  • Can't take criticism

These traits are classic for narcissistic personality disorder (NPD), which falls under Cluster B personality disorders.

  • Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) involves a pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others, deceit, impulsivity, aggression, and lack of remorse - not the traits Mr. Jack shows.
  • So calling Mr. Jack a case of ASPD is incorrect, hence option C is the "wrong" statement.

Personality Disorder Clusters (DSM-5):

Cluster A (Odd/Eccentric):

  • Paranoid PD
  • Schizoid PD
  • Schizotypal PD

Cluster B (Dramatic/Emotional/Erratic):

  • Antisocial PD
  • Borderline PD
  • Histrionic PD
  • Narcissistic PD ← Mr. Jack fits here

Cluster C (Anxious/Fearful):

  • Avoidant PD
  • Dependent PD
  • Obsessive-Compulsive PD

questions.text: A 5-week-old male infant is seen in the clinic for a routine follow-up visit. He has had worsening emesis over the past 2 weeks that occurs after all feedings and is yellow in color. He has had no fever or respiratory symptoms, but he is progressively becoming more fussy. The infant has lost 110 g since his last visit 2 weeks ago. He is too fussy to obtain an accurate abdominal examination. Of the following, this infant's diagnostic evaluation would most likely show?
questions.solution:
