questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of strabismus (squint) in children
questions.solution:
Convergent Squint (Esotropia)

Convergent squint, or esotropia, is the inward deviation of one eye, and is the most common type of squint in children. It can be unilateral (one eye always deviates) or alternating (either eye may deviate).

Clinico-Etiological Types:

  1. Infantile Esotropia
    • Onset: 1-2 months, can occur up to 6 months.
    • Constant, large angle of deviation (>30°).
    • Binocular vision does not develop; alternate fixation in primary gaze.
    • Associations: Inferior oblique overaction, dissociated vertical deviation (DVD), latent horizontal nystagmus.
    • Treatment: Surgery (preferably before 1 year). Amblyopia treatment by patching is done first.
  2. Accommodative Esotropia
    • Caused by overaction of convergence associated with accommodation.
    • Most common between ages 2-3 years.
    • Types:
      • Refractive: Associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D), correctable by glasses.
      • Non-refractive: Caused by abnormal AC/A ratio; treated with bifocals or miotics.
      • Mixed: Combination of hypermetropia and high AC/A ratio; treated with glasses for distance and +3 DS for near.
  3. Acquired Non-Accommodative Esotropias
    • Includes essential acquired esotropia, acute concomitant esotropia, cyclic esotropia, etc.
    • Essential Acquired Esotropia: Occurs after 6 months of age; includes basic type, convergence excess type, and divergence insufficiency type.
    • Treatment: Surgery after correcting refractive error and amblyopia.
  4. Sensory Esotropia
    • Resulting from monocular lesions (e.g., cataract, retinoblastoma) that affect binocular vision development.
  5. Consecutive Esotropia
    • Occurs due to overcorrection of exotropia during surgery.

This classification aids in identifying causes and selecting appropriate treatments for convergent squint.

questions.text: What is the effect produced and the wavelength of Nd:YAG laser used in capsulotomy for posterior capsular opacification?
questions.solution:
Properties of Laser Light in Ophthalmology

Laser Types and Their Effects:


  1. Argon Laser (514 nm)
    • Atomic Environment: Argon gas
    • Effect: Photocoagulation
  2. Krypton Laser (647 nm)
    • Atomic Environment: Krypton gas
    • Effect: Photocoagulation
  3. Diode Laser (840 nm)
    • Atomic Environment: Diode crystal
    • Effect: Photocoagulation
  4. Nd:YAG Laser (532 nm)
    • Atomic Environment: Nd:YAG crystals
    • Effect: Photodisruption
  5. Excimer Laser (193 nm)
    • Atomic Environment: Helium and fluorine gas
    • Effect: Photoablation
  6. Femtosecond Laser (1053 nm)
    • Atomic Environment: Neodymium-glass
    • Effect: Photodisruption

Mechanisms of Laser Effects and Therapeutic Applications:

  1. Photocoagulation:
    • Principle: Laser light is absorbed by tissue pigments, converting light into heat, coagulating and denaturing cellular components.
    • Therapeutic Uses:
      • Eyelid lesions (e.g., hemangiomas)
      • Corneal conditions (e.g., reduction of postoperative astigmatism)
      • Glaucoma treatment (e.g., laser iridotomy, trabeculoplasty)
      • Retina and choroid lesions (e.g., diabetic retinopathy, macular degeneration, retinal detachment)
  2. Photovaporization:
    • Principle: Tissue vaporization occurs at high temperatures (60-100°C), causing cauterization and tissue disintegration.
  3. Photodisruption:
    • Principle: Laser ionizes target tissue electrons, creating plasma that expands and exerts cutting pressure.
    • Therapeutic Uses: Nd:YAG and femtosecond lasers for procedures like capsulotomy and membranectomy.
  4. Photoablation:
    • Principle: UV light breaks chemical bonds in biological materials, converting them into smaller molecules.
    • Therapeutic Uses: Excimer lasers for corneal refractive surgeries like LASIK and PRK.
  5. Photoirradiation (Photochemical Effect):
    • Principle: Laser light activates a chromophore, used for photodynamic therapy (ocular tumors, choroidal neovascularization).

Key Laser Applications in Ophthalmology:

  • Retinal Disease Treatment: Panretinal photocoagulation for diabetic retinopathy, retinal hole sealing, and treatment of retinal vascular conditions.
  • Glaucoma Management: Laser procedures like iridotomy, trabeculoplasty, and cyclophotocoagulation.
  • Refractive Surgery: LASIK, PRK, and excimer laser-assisted surgeries for correcting vision problems.
  • Cataract Surgery: Femtosecond lasers in cataract incisions and flap creation for LASIK.

Complications of Laser Therapy:

  • Foveal burns, macular edema, retinal holes, hemorrhages, and accidental corneal burns.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain showing ST elevation on ECG after a stressful emotional outburst. Angiography Findings are normal but cardiac imaging demonstrates ballooning of left ventricle in systole with akinesia of distal part of LV wall. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Apical ballooning of the Heart -Takotsubo (octopus pot)
  • RV hypokinesia with Apical sparing - mc Connell sign - PTE
  • Pericardial collection with RA/RV Diastolic collapse - Cardiac tamponade
  • Asymmetrical thickening of Interventricular septum and systolic Anterior Motion of Mitral Valve Leaflet - HOCM

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, at 37 weeks gestation presents with a breech fetus confirmed by ultrasound. She has no prior uterine surgeries, and amniotic fluid levels are normal. The obstetrician decides to attempt an external cephalic version (ECV). What is the most likely complication of ECV in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of ECV is transient fetal bradycardia, occurring in about 5-10% of cases. This typically resolves spontaneously and does not result in long-term adverse outcomes. Continuous fetal monitoring during and after the procedure is critical to detect and manage such complications promptly.

Other Complications to Consider:

  • Uterine rupture: Rare, primarily in women with a history of uterine surgery.
  • Abruptio placentae: Uncommon but potentially serious, associated with improper technique or excessive force.
  • Preterm labor: Possible but less frequent, particularly when performed at term under appropriate monitoring.

This case highlights the importance of real-time ultrasound guidance and fetal heart rate monitoring during ECV.

Topic: External Cephalic Version

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG): Practice Bulletin No. 197 - Fetal Malpresentation

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of recurrent preeclampsia is found to have high uterine artery resistance during her first-trimester ultrasound. Which molecule involved in trophoblast invasion is most likely dysregulated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

A) Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)

  • VEGF promotes angiogenesis and vascular remodeling. While it plays a role in pregnancy, dysregulation of VEGF itself is less directly associated with preeclampsia compared to its inhibitors.

B) Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β)

  • TGF-β influences various cellular processes, including differentiation and invasion. However, it is not a primary molecule implicated in the pathophysiology of preeclampsia.

C) Placental growth factor (PlGF)

  • PlGF is crucial for placental angiogenesis. Decreased levels are seen in preeclampsia, but its dysregulation is secondary to an increase in anti-angiogenic factors such as sFlt-1.

D) Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1)

  • Correct Answer. sFlt-1 is an anti-angiogenic protein that binds to VEGF and PlGF, reducing their bioavailability. Elevated levels of sFlt-1 are strongly associated with preeclampsia and impair trophoblast invasion and placental perfusion.

Topic: Pathophysiology of preeclampsia

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of pregestational diabetes presents for her 20-week ultrasound scan. The scan reveals an abnormal cardiac finding. The mother had poorly controlled blood glucose levels during the first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most specific cardiac anomaly associated with pregestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) is the most specific cardiac anomaly associated with pregestational diabetes, particularly when maternal blood glucose is poorly controlled during the first trimester. TGA occurs when the pulmonary artery and aorta are switched, leading to severe cyanosis after birth. Pregestational diabetes increases the risk of TGA and other congenital heart defects, especially when glucose control is suboptimal during early pregnancy.

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) (A) and Atrial septal defect (ASD) (B) are common cardiac defects but are not as specifically associated with maternal diabetes as TGA.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot (D) is a significant congenital defect but is not as strongly linked with maternal diabetes as TGA.

Thus, TGA is the most specific congenital cardiac anomaly seen in pregnancies with pregestational diabetes.

Topic: Congenital anomalies in pregestational diabetes

questions.text: Which is the Gold Standard Investigation for confirming the diagnosis of myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis.

Patients with recent or ongoing viral syndromes have been classified into three levels of myocarditis diagnosis.

  1. Possible subclinical acute myocarditis is diagnosed when a typical viral syndrome occurs without cardiac symptoms, but with elevated biomarkers of cardiac injury, ECG suggestive of acute injury, and/or reduced left ventricular ejection fraction or regional wall motion abnormality.
  2. Probable acute myocarditis is diagnosed when the above criteria are met and accompanied by cardiac symptoms, such as shortness of breath or chest pain, which can result from pericarditis or myocarditis. When clinical findings of pericarditis are accompanied by elevated troponin or CK-MB or abnormal cardiac wall motion, the terms perimyocarditis or myopericarditis are sometimes used.
  3. Definite myocarditis is diagnosed when there is histologic or immunohistologic evidence of inflammation on endomyocardial biopsy and does not require any other laboratory or clinical criteria

When biopsy is performed, the key Dallas criteria for myocarditis include lymphocytic infiltrate with evidence of myocyte necrosis and are negative in 80-90% of patients with clinical myocarditis. Negative Dallas criteria can reflect sampling error or early resolution of lymphocytic infiltrates, but may also be influenced by the insensitivity of the test when inflammation results from cytokines and antibody-mediated injury.

questions.text: Biosafety level of SARS COV-
questions.solution:
Biosafety levels (BSL) are used to identify the protective measures needed in a laboratory setting to protect workers, the environment, and the public. The levels are defined in Biosafety in Biomedical Laboratories (the BMBL). BSL-3 laboratories are used to study infectious agents or toxins that may be transmitted through the air and cause potentially lethal infections. Researchers perform all experiments in a biosafety cabinet. BSL-3 laboratories are designed to be easily decontaminated

Cultures of SARS-CoV-2 should be handled in a biosafety level 3 (BSL-3) laboratory using BSL practices

Inoculation of animals with infectious wild-type SARS CoV-2 should be conducted in an animal biosafety level 3 (ABSL-3) facility using absl-3 practices and respiratory protection.

Let us see the various biosafety levels


Reference: https://www.cdc.gov/covid/php/lab/?CDC_AAref_Val=https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/lab/lab-biosafety-guidelines.html

questions.text: A female presented with increased TSH and very low T4. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A low T4 and a high TSH suggest the diagnosis of primary hypothyroidism.



The commonest cause of primary hypothyroidism is Autoimmune.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding. Endometrial biopsy reveals hyperplasia with atypia. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
In postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the risk of progression to endometrial cancer is high. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Cyclic progestins:

  • Progestins can be used to manage simple or complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • However, for hyperplasia with atypia, they are less effective in preventing progression to endometrial carcinoma.

B) Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUD):

  • The LNG-IUD is effective in cases of hyperplasia without atypia or for patients desiring fertility preservation.
  • In postmenopausal women or cases with atypia, definitive surgical management is preferred due to the high risk of progression to cancer.

C) Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (Correct Answer):

  • The presence of atypia on biopsy significantly increases the risk of coexistent or progression to endometrial carcinoma (up to 40%).
  • Surgical removal of the uterus and ovaries is the definitive treatment and eliminates the risk of malignancy.

D) Endometrial ablation:

  • This is not suitable for managing hyperplasia with atypia, as it does not allow for histopathological evaluation of the endometrium.
  • It also does not treat the underlying condition effectively in high-risk cases.

Topic: Endometrial hyperplasia

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 149: Endometrial Hyperplasia. Obstetrics & Gynecology. 2015.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an impulsive control disorder?
questions.solution:
Trichotillomania is no longer classified as an impulse control disorder - this is a nuanced but important update based on modern psychiatric classification systems.

According to DSM-5:

  • Trichotillomania (Hair-Pulling Disorder) is classified under Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5).
  • It was previously grouped with Impulse Control Disorders in DSM-IV, but this changed in DSM-5 due to its similarities with OCD (e.g., repetitive behaviors, anxiety relief).
  • People with Trichotillomania experience an irresistible urge to pull out their hair, often resulting in noticeable hair loss.
  • This behavior is not driven by pleasure, unlike typical impulse control disorders (e.g., pyromania or kleptomania), but by tension relief or gratification similar to OCD compulsions. Therefore, it was reclassified in DSM-5 (2013).

questions.text: A 32-year-old unmarried woman from a low socioeconomic status family believes that a rich boy from her neighborhood is in deep love with her. The boy clearly denies his love towards this lady. Still the lady insists that his denial is a secret affirmation of his love towards her. She makes desperate attempts to meet the boy despite resistance from her family. She also develops sadness at times when her effort to meet the boy does not materialize. She is able to maintain her daily routine. She however, remains preoccupied with the thoughts of this boy. She is likely to be suffering from.
questions.solution:
• This woman is displaying signs of a delusional belief, specifically a delusion of love (erotomania) where someone falsely believes another person (often of higher status) is in love with them despite clear evidence to the contrary.
  • Delusional Disorder - Erotomanic Type, which is a classic example of a disorder of the content of thought.

Why not the other options?

A. Flow of thought disorder: This refers to disorganized thinking (e.g., flight of ideas, loosening of associations), which is not described here.

B. Affective disorder: Mood symptoms are secondary. Affective disorders like depression or mania would feature mood as the primary disturbance.

D. Dissociative disorder: These involve disruptions in memory, identity, or consciousness (e.g., amnesia, fugue), which are not evident here.

REFERENCE: DSM 5

questions.text: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis develops as a toxicity to?
questions.solution: Patients with poor GFR, when given gadolinium can develop into nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, it begins with dermogenic fibrosis and progresses into multiorgan fibrosis and death

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and abnormal vaginal discharge. She has a history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. On examination, her abdomen is tender, and cervical motion tenderness is noted. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a tubo-ovarian mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, including lower abdominal pain, fever, abnormal discharge, and the finding of a tubo-ovarian mass, are highly suggestive of PID, which can result in tubo-ovarian abscess formation.

Optionwise Explanation:

A) Ovarian cyst:

  • Ovarian cysts can present with abdominal pain, but they typically do not cause fever, abnormal vaginal discharge, or cervical motion tenderness.
  • The presence of a tubo-ovarian mass on ultrasound raises suspicion for PID rather than a simple ovarian cyst.

B) Ectopic pregnancy:

  • Ectopic pregnancy can present with lower abdominal pain, but it typically does not cause fever or vaginal discharge.
  • Ectopic pregnancies often present with amenorrhea or a positive pregnancy test, which is not mentioned in the case. Additionally, a tubo-ovarian mass could be seen in ectopic pregnancies, but the clinical signs of fever and cervical motion tenderness are more suggestive of PID.

C) Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) (Correct Answer):

  • PID is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's clinical presentation. It is a sexually transmitted infection that involves the upper genital tract, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.
  • Common risk factors for PID include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use, which are noted in this case.
  • The patient's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, fever, abnormal vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness, along with a tubo-ovarian mass on ultrasound, are classic findings of PID.
  • A tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA) is a complication of PID, where the infection leads to the formation of a mass due to inflammation and pus accumulation around the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

D) Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis can cause pelvic pain, but it typically does not present with fever or abnormal vaginal discharge.
  • Endometriosis is usually characterized by chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia, rather than the acute signs seen in PID.
  • The presence of a tubo-ovarian mass is more consistent with PID than with endometriosis.

Topic: Pelvic Inflammatory disease

Reference: Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) Diagnosis and Management 2021

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and a firm, irregular uterus on examination. An ultrasound shows multiple hypoechoic lesions within the myometrium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) are the most common benign tumors of the uterus, presenting with symptoms like heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and an enlarged, irregular uterus. Ultrasound typically shows hypoechoic lesions.

Optionwise explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this case is uterine fibroids (also known as leiomyomas).

A) Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, commonly on the ovaries, pelvic peritoneum, and other pelvic structures. While endometriosis can cause pelvic pain and heavy menstrual bleeding, the findings on ultrasound would typically not show hypoechoic lesions within the myometrium, which is characteristic of uterine fibroids.

B) Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis occurs when endometrial tissue grows within the muscular layer of the uterus. It often presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain, but on ultrasound, it would typically show a heterogeneous or diffusely enlarged uterus, not well-defined hypoechoic lesions as in fibroids.

C) Uterine fibroids: Fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus and are the most common cause of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain in women of reproductive age. On ultrasound, fibroids often appear as hypoechoic (dark) lesions within the myometrium, which is exactly what is described in the case.

D) Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, particularly postmenopausal bleeding, and may show an irregular endometrial stripe on ultrasound. It is less likely to present with the characteristic firm, irregular uterus and hypoechoic myometrial lesions seen in this case.

Topic: Uterine fibroids

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a routine Pap smear result showing normal cytology. When should she be screened again?
questions.solution:
For women under 30, routine Pap smear screening should occur every 3 years if the result is normal. Screening intervals may vary based on risk factors and age.


Topic: Cervical cytology

Reference: American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP). Management of women with abnormal cervical cancer screening tests. ASCCP 2019 guidelines.
